content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a wonderful game for what it represents. The plot is fantastic and I love how it uses true events with slightly renamed consoles and games, far better than if they made up all the consoles and games. The game gives you a lot of choice, is very simple to understand and with so many different possibilities and outcomes, the game has yet to become stale for me so far.However, in my hour so far of playing, I am already finding it very hard to make perfect games. Whilst game reports are a very good way to get information about good and bad combos, the reviews are lacking in depth with some simply saying things like 'Enjoyed it' and 'Good'. If the reviewers went into more depth like they sometimes do when mentioning things like 'medieval works really well with strategy' then I'd much prefer the reviews and actually find them useful, however, as it stands, the best way to get information on your game is to file a game report. Whilst I have not played this game for too long, my first impressions are for the most part very positive. The game is very simple to play and is perfect for some relaxing late-night gaming. The game adds enough challenge with its numerous choices and certainly does require a lot of thought into some decisions in order to maintain enough money to save yourself from going bankrupt, however isn't impossibly difficult to grasp. Overall, my opinion on 'Game Dev Tycoon' is very positive, however I do feel the lack of in-depth reviews really does hinder its potential. But this is one con among many pros and should certainly not put you off playing this wonderfully unique experience.Rating: 3/4

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Game Dev Tycoon is a fun little casual game well worth picking up while on sale. You start as a single person in your garage and work your way up to the CEO of an AAA game studio. Anyone who has played a variety of games over the years will enjoy coming up with their favorite game combos and thinking from the end of an indie game developer. I think the style of the artwork may convey a generic-ville type feeling but it's a proper game. There is no in-game purchasing micro-transaction garbage. The game has a definite goal and is not a mindless grinding simulator. I am a slow gamer but it took me about thirty hours before I was able to complete all the achievements in the game. I will likely put another ten hours in just to see how fast I can beat the game now that I have proper experience in it.I think some of the negative reviews that are on here are frustrated with replay value and min/maxing their games. I'd like to address that. This game is most fun when experienced at the beginning without a guide. If you go in with a guide you're just going to want to hit all the hard points right off the bat and you'll completely lose the fun the game, even if you succeed. Don't be afraid to try things and learn, as the game is very good with rewarding you regardless of success or failure. For example if you decide to try a game combination/configuration that does not work, the game permanently records a reminder in your history when you write your game report. Should you decide to restart your game, it will give you the option to retain that knowledge in the new game. Game Dev Tycoon is also good about not giving you too much to handle up front, easing you into the development process, while at the same time not giving you any choices that are completely useless. So feel free to experiment with new opportunities! When it is beneficial for you to use a publisher the option will appear (never too soon.) and even the random 'events' that occur give you a bonus even if you make the 'wrong choice'.When it comes to replay again I believe it relies on not getting a game guide right off the bat. You'll go bankrupt a few times learning but it's okay, like I mentioned your 'progress' is still pretty much saved. Once you get the swing of things you'll quickly level your studio up quickly to where you were previously. With a guide you'll just be frustrated you are not hitting 10/10 games every single time and just quit at the beginning.

												Love it.This is pretty much a no brainer, for any tycoon fan at least.Despite not being extremely important, the graphics are really nice, and don't get boring to look at (which, let's face it, you'll spend a lot of time looking at it), and are followed by a regular soundtrack. The gameplay is incredibly good, allowing you to train your character, and hire a couple more (and train them, too). You'll also be able to upgrade your office once you've earned (milked) enough money from your fans, and you'll also be able to research new technologies and such throughout the years.Eventually, you'll even be able to start your own MMO games, and that's when the real milking begins. Or it should. That's probably the one thing I feel it's a bit off with GDT. The MMO system is bad, in my opinion. And, since I'm not really into modding, I've never really tried any of the mods available, which are many. But I've read, and heard from friends, that there are some really really good mods.I've actually spent more hours playing this than steam actually states, for some reason, so, that's something to take into consideration, too.I'd recommend this game any day of the year.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Game Dev Tycoon. More Clinical Than I Prefer, But Fun.Genre: Indie Simulation Management Game. Developed and Published by: Greenheart GamesPlatform: Windows, Mac and LinuxBusiness Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay ThoughtsThis is my first and, so far only, journey into this genre. Game Dev Tycoon premise is about traveling back in time and building a game development studio from the ground up with knowledge of what's to come. Personally, I think I would have done a lot of bets on the lottery but hey, priorities right? Build your company from nothing and try to make it to the top in the optimal way possible. From working out of your garage into your own studio to eventually commanding a team of about 10 people. GDT covers a lot of different aspects of game development including developing your own technologies, advertising, fan bases and more. There’s about six to seven hours of content to complete a single run-through. It’s a casual experience with a numbers-increasing-over-time reward feeling to it.Building a game is somewhat straightforward. After selecting the name, topic, genre and platform the game will be built for, development will start. This involves little bubbles flying to the top of the screen increasing four different point stats: Bugs, Design, Technology and Research. Design and technology points are useful for different aspects of game development. Research points are used for, well, researching new technologies. The fourth stat is how many bugs your game has created. You are free to publish a game with bugs but there may be an understandable backlash by fans and sales might be affected. There will then be three development stage windows that will popup. These will have sliders that guide how much time is spent on certain aspects of the title in process Generally, you want to optimize your time for what the genre/topic prefers. There’s also chances to include/exclude certain costly features such as better sound & graphics or other potentially important features. Once you think your game is ready and finished, you’ll gain experience (there’s a lot of different sliders) and then have the option to either release the game or trash it. Keep in mind that there are monthly costs so trashing a game should only be done if you’ve royally screwed it up.There’s some additional nuance to the simulation, especially once the company grows bigger and moves out of the garage. There’s the hiring of additional developers for different training into different specialties. There’s deciding how much advertising in traditional and non-traditional media the company will manage, choosing which new game technology to research, and much more. A lot of it is handled by staring at bars and numbers steadily increasing as your team/company gets better at its job. All of which is simply handled with popup windows and mouse clicks. There’s only a single level of difficulty and it’s enough to keep you honest but not overly punishing. Unless you make some really silly mistakes. GDT is good for an amusing time through game development history starting from the C64/oldPC era to slightly ahead of our current times in 2013. Though the biggest you can reach is a mid-range development studio. No true AAA 100+ man teams. Although, all things considered, maybe its best we don't simulate that...GDT’s Biggest Strength and WeaknessWhile the point of GDT is that you know what’s coming up next, it’s also its biggest problem. It makes the game just a little too predictable. It takes the risk out of the game since if my company was ever approaching bankruptcy, all I had to do was publish a game I knew would do well on the PC platform and suddenly huge amounts of cash. Whether that was a post-apocalyptic RPG, aka: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, a history strategy title or a military action game, I’d get my money and then some from the project. It was almost always guaranteed they’d work out so long as I hadn’t been making them constantly. The game is a bit too clinical about how games are made for my taste. What sets your game apart from the rest besides your development talents is the name its given. There’s no real branding done, universe building or whatnot. At least, not organically. These are mostly just gripes and not game-breaking problems. PC SettingsPC settings menu is a bit lacking in user choice. The settings menu gives you language choices, tutorials & hints with present on/off switches and an animation quality slider. The quality slider presents performance and quality presets though I doubt you’ll need it to run at the performance preset unless you’re running this game on a toaster. In fullscreen mode, which is really borderless windowed, the game auto-adjusts to whatever resolution your desktop is running. In windowed, it runs in a square resolution. V-sync is always on. As the game is entirely mouse driven, there’s nothing to be remapped. There’s a single audio slider for the game’s volume with on/off toggles for sound effects and music. I would have preferred there to be multiple audio sliders, but oh well. By the way, there’s only four save slots and they only save the most recent games. Final ThoughtsMy opinion is mostly neutral when it comes to Game Dev Tycoon. It's fun for the one playthrough but after that, there's not much to hook me in. It's filled with plenty of references and nods to games, platforms and the culture throughout the game which make the first run-through worthwhile. But, it's a little too predictable and a little too clinical for my taste. There's not a lot of true creative control over the games made and there's some missing aspects of game development not featured. Not that it makes the game bad, just not really what I'm looking for. Still, I can't knock it for doing what they sold the game as but I'd keep that thought in mind if you're interested in it.Read the Review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												In Game Dev Tycoon, there are a wide range of games you could release on a variety of consoles throughout the years. You start right when gaming takes off or so, with two options to develop for, as time passes on you get more options. Those options are twists on the real names of consoles that have gone through over time, as well as the companies who developed them. A big part of the game is research. What is research exactly? You get research from doing various things such as completing contract work, which gives you money for completion, but takes your money if you don't complete it in time. You can also get it from other things like making games. What is research used for? Upgrades to your games to make them even better and bring in those big scores. Big scores means big money to make more big games. It turns into an endless cycle, until you're a billionaire. Your games can have different topics which you have to research, and can be in a variety of genres. It's up to you to decide what genre and topic works best, and where you should divert your resources during development. You can also hype up your game by putting out ads, or going to the game's equivalent of E3 and setting up a booth. Hyping up a bad game is bad for your company, but hyping up a really good game will reward you greatly. In the second stage of the game you can start to hire staff. They're really useful but aren't that great at first. Remember to train them up, but don't forget to work on your own character as well.Game Dev Tycoon also has a modding community, although some of the mods don't work very well. You can still find plenty of good mods that add content and expand the game though. I didn't get mods myself until after my first or second playthrough though.Some bugs and annoyances I've found are that late game, with too many bubbles your game can lag, although a mod can fix that on the workshop. Also I've recently run into some issues with tabbing out and changing the size of the screen. I haven't run into any game breaking bugs, but watch out if you plan on modding because some of them can conflict, and break the game.I'll give this game a 6.75/10. I enjoyed it a lot but I feel that it does have some issues. I still recommend it, though.

												If you ever wanted to have fun and see how you would do in making your own games in a fantasy setting, this is a very good game. I have had fun playing it multiple times and some are just for ridiculous games and others are just "remakes" of real games that I love. I always love how I tend to make Romance of the Three Kingdoms a 10 across the review boards. Check it out if it's on sale but I believe it is totally worth full price.Graphics: 8 - Great for a simulation game, love the colors.Sound: 8.5 - Music is alright but great for this type of game.Gameplay: 8.5 - Good gameplay, I always enjoy trying to get the achievements everytime I play.Story: 8.5 - Just you trying to bring a company from your garage to a AAA studio.

Posted: December 28, 2014
												This game is AWESOME!Honestly, any game where you can create best-selling games which have names like 'Drop That Soap' and make advanced consoles called the 'Compubox Too' is one worth investing in. There are so many great mods in this game, but I have not invested in these too much yet.I recently played through the game in a 6/7-hour game and actually discovered several features which I had not previously discovered (such as the homage to this service which is dubbed 'Grid') and, not only was it fun to play, but the experience was different; and no two files will likely have the same development path for topics, as all of the topics appear in a random order.This game is one of my personal favourites, not only for the hilarious titles that can come up, but for the achievements which bay homage to classic games (such as Pong and Doom). I would recommend this to any casual gamer who is happy to spend countless hours playing this legendary game.10/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a strategy game developed by Greenheart games. You begin the game by naming your character with limited customization and naming your company, then with a very helpful tutorial system, you're off to create games as you see fit.When you start, the only thing you can do is create a game, you can make it text based or 2-D gameplay, but as you progress through the years you will be able to research new things such as the ability to make a 3-D engine, better A.I., environmental effects, all that stuff. To get these research ideas, you must get research points by making a game, engine, or doing something like creating a report on what you did wrong when developing your game. When you begin making your game, you can choose the genre, which topic it will be based on (Ancient history, ninjas, spies) and choosing which systems it will be onYou can also create your own engine with many of these research skills, which can cost quite a lot sum of dosh. When developing your game, you have to use 3 sliders to see how much time you want to spend on a part of a game, for example, do you focus on the story more than the game or vice versa? Graphics or sound, A.I. or Dialogue? As you develop your game, Journalists will ask for interviews and ask on you're opinion on things such as what's important in a genre of a game, you can also hype up the game by saying stuff like "*Name* will be one of the greatest", you can also sign missions such as a plan to get women into gaming which will cost you, but earn you a lot of fans and respect. Once you've created your game, you will gain experience in pretty much all your skills such as your story writing, gameplay designing, sound and graphics, etc. The game will also then  be reviewed by 4 reviewers, you may start by getting 5s, 4s, and probably 2s, but once you've managed to get your first 10 out of 10, you will want to raise your hand in success.If you've done badly, you can generate a game report which can give you advise, such as the Commodore 64 has a large adventure fanbase, or the PC community has a large strategy fanbase, and whether things such as dialogue is important for certain genres.However, if you still manage to do badly, you will enter bankrupcy and will have to take a loan from the bank, fail that, game over.As you earn more money, you can move into bigger offices where you can recruit more staff members as well as make the place look very pretty.As you make good games you will gain fans, who will definatly buy your games and if you got 100K of them, you'll be able to self publish your games, you can also sign publish contracts with companies such as úbersoft or Electronic Mass Productions to gain notice in the industry, but they'll call the shots on what you make.Later in the game you can also build your custom console to release onto the market.I gotta say, the gameplay is pretty damn addicting, so much so I've been spending 6 hours into a single play session which I never really do a lot, and that says something for me.Nothing to say in the visual department, it looks clean and reminds me of a few flash games.The sound is pretty good too, nice beeps and bloops and the music keeps a smile on my face 99% of the time.As far as complaints go.....well, there isn't any on the top of my head to be honest, I was too occupied in making games and having too much fun to notice any.Overall, Game Dev Tycoon is a brilliant game and you should absolutly purchase it as soon as you can.I'd play it for decades.9/10

Posted: May 31, 2014
												One of the most fun Strategy games I have ever come across. Packed full of nostalgia, easter eggs, and parodies. This would be the one app I would pay for to have it on my smart phone. Super entertaining and relaxing. If you're playing this game and not having fun... you're doing it wrong.Tutorials are welcomed in this game as there is far to much to pick up on in one play through. The achievements are superbly designed and actually seem the point to play. The points system when releasing a game is a bit confusing...All in all on a scale from 1 to 10 its... cocaine for the brain my friends!!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a strategy game developed by Greenheart games. You begin the game by naming your character with limited customization and naming your company, then with a very helpful tutorial system, you're off to create games as you see fit.When you start, the only thing you can do is create a game, you can make it text based or 2-D gameplay, but as you progress through the years you will be able to research new things such as the ability to make a 3-D engine, better A.I., environmental effects, all that stuff. To get these research ideas, you must get research points by making a game, engine, or doing something like creating a report on what you did wrong when developing your game. When you begin making your game, you can choose the genre, which topic it will be based on (Ancient history, ninjas, spies) and choosing which systems it will be onYou can also create your own engine with many of these research skills, which can cost quite a lot sum of dosh. When developing your game, you have to use 3 sliders to see how much time you want to spend on a part of a game, for example, do you focus on the story more than the game or vice versa? Graphics or sound, A.I. or Dialogue? As you develop your game, Journalists will ask for interviews and ask on you're opinion on things such as what's important in a genre of a game, you can also hype up the game by saying stuff like "*Name* will be one of the greatest", you can also sign missions such as a plan to get women into gaming which will cost you, but earn you a lot of fans and respect. Once you've created your game, you will gain experience in pretty much all your skills such as your story writing, gameplay designing, sound and graphics, etc. The game will also then  be reviewed by 4 reviewers, you may start by getting 5s, 4s, and probably 2s, but once you've managed to get your first 10 out of 10, you will want to raise your hand in success.If you've done badly, you can generate a game report which can give you advise, such as the Commodore 64 has a large adventure fanbase, or the PC community has a large strategy fanbase, and whether things such as dialogue is important for certain genres.However, if you still manage to do badly, you will enter bankrupcy and will have to take a loan from the bank, fail that, game over.As you earn more money, you can move into bigger offices where you can recruit more staff members as well as make the place look very pretty.As you make good games you will gain fans, who will definatly buy your games and if you got 100K of them, you'll be able to self publish your games, you can also sign publish contracts with companies such as úbersoft or Electronic Mass Productions to gain notice in the industry, but they'll call the shots on what you make.Later in the game you can also build your custom console to release onto the market.I gotta say, the gameplay is pretty damn addicting, so much so I've been spending 6 hours into a single play session which I never really do a lot, and that says something for me.Nothing to say in the visual department, it looks clean and reminds me of a few flash games.The sound is pretty good too, nice beeps and bloops and the music keeps a smile on my face 99% of the time.As far as complaints go.....well, there isn't any on the top of my head to be honest, I was too occupied in making games and having too much fun to notice any.Overall, Game Dev Tycoon is a brilliant game and you should absolutly purchase it as soon as you can.I'd play it for decades.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												This game is awesome. Period.Game Dev Tycoon is a game about starting from the bottom to rise up the ladder and become a sucessful Game Developer. There are many various events that occur during the timeline (early 80's +) like new consoles, office upgrades, offers from "Agent Blowfish" to savatage other game companies, and scammers from other countries. It is very easy to play and understand, but can be hard to survive the years without going bankrupt.When I started playing, I started 2 or 3 saves and went bankrupt in the Garage on each one. Then on my 4th, I survived long enough to move into the first Office. I stayed there for a while and even managed to survive to the first Office upgrade. But alas, I went into the land of Bankrupcy once more. Then, I got the gist of the game and tried again, this time with some new stratagies. Now, I'm waaay past the last event and the console lab. All my employees are 1000+ on every aspect and still going strong. In my games, I make maybe 4-6 new games during the start, then I just keep making sequels of them (For Example: I make a Music/Simulation game called Musik Maker, then I just keep making Musik Makers on and on every now and then (Musik Maker 2, Musik Maker 3, Musik Maker 4, etc.)). I may occasionally make another new series but I usually stick to the same games, and all my games are always named after real games! :DAnother great thing about Game Dev Tycoon was Mod Support. If you go on the Forums, there are plenty of Mods available and being made (The game was made in JavaScript, HTML, and CSS so it shouldn't be too hard for Programmers to mod). And you are probably thinking, "HACKS, CHEATS, UNLEGITNESS! NO MODS FOR ME!". It turns out, most of the Mods are just Expansion Packs adding new consoles or events or options. To my knowledge there is only 1 Cheat Mod, and it's called Cheat Mod... :P It's actually pretty fun to use on a seperate save (Call it "CHEATERZ" or something) because you can skip to any place in the timeline and when you are developing a game, there are little plus sign orbs below that add points to your game design and technology (I have made games with 50K points each :D). I'd reccommend Mods to users who have played Game Dev Tycoon a lot and are bored of the origanal and are looking for more and for those who just want more.The game itself takes maybe 5+ hours to squeeze all the story out and is actually a bit short (But with expansion mods, Game Dev Tycoon = MOAR FUN!). Some of the achivements are really hard to get (Oh yeah, MODS DONT DISABLE ACHIVEMENTS! So if you are REALLY stuck, the Cheat Mod comes in handy :} ) and a bunch of them are Easter Eggs (I'm not spoiling :)).Overall, this game is really worth getting. 10$ is a BIT much, but it's so worth it. If it's on sale, EVEN BETTER! WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? GET IT NOW!!!11/10"Achivement Unlocked: Turn it up to 11"

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Do I develop a text based adventure or try to make a sim game? Ok text based adventure just to get my foot in the ground.  Oh no, what system? Can I afford a licensing fee? Is there enough market share to make it worth my time? Did I even focus on the correct attributes!? Are adventures even popular at the moment? Ok ok let's release the game, if it fails I'll be bankrupt and that will be the end of me. 7, 6, 6, 8Ok not too bad! I'll live to make a new game! Well do I make a new game or upgrade my game engine!? Should I hire new staff or train existing staff? What to do what to do?These questions and more will be up to you and your new game company. If your itching for a tycoon experience this should be right up your ally. Make games, earn money, hire staff, fire staff, change offices, create game engines, even make your own console. All of these things and more are awaiting for you in this lovely gem of a game. You may even learn a thing or two of the history of consoles, even if they are using fake names. I picked this up during the 2013 Holliday sale and wasn't expecting much, but what I got was a "just one more game I need good reviews!" Kind of addiction. I didn't put it down till I got every achievement! If you were a fan of Zoo Tycoon or Roller Coaster Tycoon like I am you should give this game a shot. This game doesn't disappoint! I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Game Dev Tycoon is a truly great, unique game. With enthralling gameplay with interesting twists and turns, dodgy Nigerian scammers and desperate fans, this is the juggernaut of the admittedly small Game Dev Game World. (Makes sense, right?) Follow your well-dressed character through time, starting with your bog-standard PC in your garage in the 70/80s, all the way to your futuristic HQ with a huge army of coders and some irritatingly needy uni students in your backroom... Create games for consoles ranging from the much loved Gameling to the futuristic Mbox One! You can let you and your team create a Prison Simulation in which the main goal is to pick up people's soap for them, or an action game funded by the Explody-Red-Barrel-Scientist-Guys, make 30 Million dollars in profit on a Vocabulary game, and lots more.Playability: 8/10Replayability: 9/10Fun: 10/101)Must Buy2)Should Buy3) Should buy only in sale4)Shouldn't Buy unless heavily discounted5)Shouldn't get unless free6) Shouldn't play even if free

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Game Dev Tyccon is a video game business simulation by Greenheart Games based on the Japanese IOS and Android game Game Dev Story (Originally: Kairopark) that I have spent far too many of hours on, but I have no regrets.When Game Dev Tyccon starts, you get to create a character of the gender of your choice while the game also offers you a good range of ethnicities to choose from, after which you get to sit at your desk in your dusty and rusty garage, to create your very first video game.At the beginning of the game you only get a few categories to choose from, topic, genre and the platform for your game. As the game goes on and you develop more games, games you will have to research in order to unlock more topics and categories, your games will get to be more detailed and specific, especially when you start to develop your very own consoles.The point of the game is to make games that work will, games that will sell and get you fans, so that your company flourishes. There is a lot to do in the game in terms of unlocking categories, topics as well as contract for some of that side money. It took me  a little while to understand the importance of researching my released games in order to figure out what had worked and what hadn't, which ended up being incredibly helpful. When a game is finished, aspects you chose to priorities will receive XP so that they can LV up, rendering even better games.After all of this, the obvious follows, your game will be reviewed by reviewers, your sales will greatly depend on the reviews you get and whether they turn out to be positive or negative.Game Dev Tycoon is a lot of fun, and a lot more complicated than what you might expect from a game like that. As a gamer, my understanding of what works well together and what doesn't goes from common sense to personal experiences, and it was very fun to see the game point out to actual game consoles that either failed terribly or changed the gaming industry altogether.Game Dev Tycoon may be similar to Game Dev Story at the core but turned out to be entirely different. In terms of how much work and thought you have to put into a game; it turned out to be a true simulation that at times became very difficult and I have lost count of the amount of times that I had to declare A woman on the internet / facebook

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon is one of those surprises that you find along your game year. I was waiting until Steam Sale to purchase this game, due to lack of reviews/people talking about it. You see, I'm a big fan of Tycoon games, and its easy to play one of this genre and see a lot of mistakes/bugs ruining the gameplay. This is not true to GDT. If I knew what I know now, I'd purchase this game right away.Combining a good mixture of good design and gameplay, Greenheart Games made me feel like the little guy in the garage building my first game. You see, with Tycoon games you usually see yourself as the manager or some kind of God Like creature. In this title I felt so compelled to strive that I couldn't wait to release my major game and everytime a so-so review came in, I felt dissapointed. The pacing is great. Along the years you see consoles rise and fall and new technologies appear. Eventually you move out of your little garage and a office takes place. Then a fellow co-worker or two...And when you realize, its been 20 years already and you're a multi-million game dev studio, with lots of employees and each one with a different skill.Although the interface is not winning Design award of the Year, it's still very user friendly, and will leave no room for doubt as to where things are and how they work.This game takes me back to the time where I found a sentiment of "wonder" in games. Greenheart Games, thanks for the experience."I can't wait for the sequel!"                    - Tarik Ventura

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												A lot of people seem to think that developing games is as easy as doing what you did the last time, but only doing it better. The gaming industry can be very finicky, and usually successful games are successful if the market and timing is just right. But to anyone that thinks that they can make video games, here ya go. Starting you off at the beginning of the video game revolution, but just after the Video Game Crash of '83, this game puts you in the role of a software designer. I use that term over video game maker because you can develop game engines, pick up white hat hacking jobs from different companies for cash and develop games for a variety of consoles. I got as far as the Playstation/N64 era with my games, and saw the release of the Dreamcast, but I failed due to poor decisions, rehashes, and bad marketing. It's not that the game is tough, you should just know that you can't expect a great game just because of a name, which is true to real life. I highly recommend this game, not only because of how real it felt, but also because of how much fun it is. If you've ever wondered if you could make video games for a living, believe me, this game is for you.

												There is a good solid 4-6 hours in this game (just one play through), especially if you can make it to the end of the game, and make the correct decisions.  The Good: - You have to make the right decisions to make the most successful game.  There isn't a lot of randomness to your game ratings. You really do feel like you are in control.  - It is fun to see the history of the gaming industry over the last 20 years or so, and relive some of your childhood by actually developing for some of your favorite consoles!The Bad:- Each time you play through the game, the same consoles and events in history happen.  It would be nice to have alternate timelines where some consoles did bad that would normally do good.- After you figure out what combos work the best, and the mechanics, there really isn't much challenge to the game.Overall, I do recommend this game, but make sure you get it on sale!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												My first thoughts about this game were contradictory - Creating games while playing game? But I've decided to give It a try especially since It showed up on sale. I was wrong, Game Dev Tycoon brings you decent fun for a few hours, depending on your end game goal. I've found this game quite challenging from start, since you can get easily bankrupted for making a series of bad decisions while learning game mechanics, but that's what It's about, right?I had a great time watching how my company grows, but after you reach top scores and end-game, It gets very repetitive.Maybe if there was more game mechanics (ingame ones are simple and game Itself limits you in styles how you create and sell your products).Overall I didn't regret buying this game on sale, but I would if I paid full price.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Genre: Casual/SimulationOverview: While the repetative nature of this game will limit the amount of fun you will have in subsequent replays, the initial playthrough was incredibly fun and addictive and took me somewhere between 6-8 hours to "finish" the game. Replay Value: After you are scored, you have the option to continue playing, but past this point no new technologies, systems, etc. will appear in the game and you are left with making games for whatever the last gen of consoles is (or for your own console). After playing around with various combinations of genres, you can import the effectiveness ratings for any new games that you make in a new playthrough.Gameplay: Many people who pick up this game have likely come across Game Dev Story from Kairosoft. Obvious influence aside, this game adds its own flavor to the game dev "genre." Without spoiling too much, eventually the game opens up to give the player many options through building a research team. The progression is streamlined and feels complete. The player starts in a garage and eventually finds himself the head of a major gaming corporation. With this progression, the complexity of the game changes drastically, but, for the most part, these changes are largely cosmetic in nature. The core gameplay is not particularly deep or even challenging. Any gaming vet will know which combinations work vs. which don't through common sense alone, without the need for a guide to hold your hand. Price/Value: Overall, expect to invest somewhere between 10-20 hours on this game. If this is something you deem fair for a $10 price tag, then by all means go for it. Those 10-20 hours will be a lot of fun. However, if longetivity is your concern, then perhaps wait for a steam sale. At the time of this writing, the game is on sale for $5. At this price I can wholeheartedly recommend you pick it up.Score: 7/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												When purchasing this game, little did I know how addicting it would be. I've played a similar game on my iPhone, but this one is by far more challenging and has more to offer.You start off in your garage, on your own, making video games. As you progress you move up into your own office and can hire people to work for you. Each game you make you choose the amount of time and effort that is put into producing certain aspects of the game. You also can research more enhancements that can be used to create your own gaming engine to produce even better games. Once a game is made and released it gets rated by four gaming magazines (those jerks can be a bit harsh at times...And yes, giving your game a name does seem to matter because if you don't one of thse guys ussually calls you on it).This game has replay value to it, which is what I enjoy. You can go back, make a new company and try and outdo yourself, try different combinations, do what ever you want. Good game, and I would suggest giving it a try.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												A very fun and unqiue Tycoon game. While we get tycoon games that make us run railroads, prisions,hosptials, movie theaters, Zoo's, and amusement parks.This tycoon game has us being our very own video game developer. Every video gamer's dream. The only downside to this game is its "rating" system on games. You can't really seem to tell what's "good", "bad" and ugly" sure it ranges from 1 to a perfect 10. But sometimes it may or may not sell well. Also working with "medium" and "large" games you can't really seem to tell that clearly what is necessarry. Also while the game gives you "hints" as to what's good for that game or not. It isn't really straight forwardly defined and it forces the player to make "judgement" calls i mean it IS a tycoon game after allWith modding including this game has limitless, endless fun. However it is sad because much like Skyrim. This game should've had a lot of these good mods in the game to begin with and not as something the modding community has to do. But then again it shows how much a community cares about the game so there is an upside.I seriously recommend this game for Tycoon fans and for all gamers who want to be that next inspiring video game developer

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Ricks Review:Summary:Gameplay: 8/10 - Simple and Qurky at times which is enjoyable, childlike and frustrating.Game Making: 9/10 - Researching new topics, engine and engine bits allows for managable customization of your game and with many mods extending the lists of these for more replayability. Pushing sliders up and down to influence how you game looks, feels and plays is key to making your game a success. While matchin the right Topic, Genre and Console is the most frustrating, obvious and simplistic thing ever devised, it sometimes causes frustration in "How do they not work!" and "OMG!!! I got a Super-Amazing game!"Console Making: 9/10 - Although not at all similar to creating a Game and only available in the late game, it is surprisingly enjoyable to create a 15 billion credit machine to compete against Vonnys and Mirconofts superboxes. Compared to game making, the choices are few to graphics, technology and optimization, and the console designs are limited to a select few (Xbox, Wii, PS2, and the Box) with upto 3 different variations depending on the console type.MMO Making: 8/10 - I listed this different from Game Making as its selling process is totally different compared to the generic game, as it can sell Forever! Unlike basic, generic games, MMOs can sell for intill the player decides to stop selling it (which can be for any reason the player decides on). The best way to keep selling the MMO is to keep advertising it and putting Addons onto it. I rated this lower because it felt limited and cannot be unlocked through standard researching but through a R&D lab (Research and Development Laboratory).Sequels Making: 7/10 - Again placed these types of games under a different review because they are similar to eachother and different to MMOs and Generic game making. Sequels in the base game are unlocked several years down the timeline but can be modded to be unlocked after you create your first game. Sequels allow for the player to create an entirely new version of a pre-made game, (Real Honour 1, 2 or 3 etc.) the ratings of your sequel will depend on the time since last game was released and if the game was made on a new engine (with other tech changing the ratings as well). However, creating a sequel replaces that game so if your sequel was rated bad and your wanted to start from the begining you cannot do this and you'll need to make a sequel of the sequel. Addon Making: 5/10 - Similar to sequels but only apply to MMOs, you can create an expansion pack for your MMO game which can encourage more people to buy the game and play it. That is really it. You can however apply Game choices like new graphics or additions, but this is it. Nothing more nothing less.Research: 10/10 - Nothing really to improve on. You can research Game Topics (Spy, Fantasy etc.), Engines, Engine Components (Animations, cutscenes etc.), Casual genre, new gameplay additions (marketing, target markets) and that is really it. After you reach late-game, you can get a Research and Development lab which is used to unlock Console Making, MMO/Addon making, Company Exhibitions and better hardware. UI: 5/10 - UI is well designed, it is simple but accessible. However is very quirky and annoying, sometime changing the game title can be awkward. Menu buttons fail to respond or work sometimes, and clicking on a button can make another thing happen. Technical ability of the UI is poor but the display is good.Audio: 10/10 - Best thing about this game is the relaxing, jazz-style music which plays.Moddability: 4/10 - I don't understand how to mod this game, so I rely on the community to judge half of the review for this part. Lots of mods available from similar topics and research to gameplay changes and addons. Workshop compatability helps as it installs mods to your files directly and hosts several pages of fun and awesome mods. However I do occasionally run into faults with modding and workshop, from mods not being installed properly and requiring to access the game, turning the mods on and restarting the game for them to work. Although  easy to live with, just frustrating and takes time away from playing the game.Main Points:Great gameplay, from heavily customizable games to creating amazing supermachines to compete against Vonny or Mirconoft.Great jazz audio which is relaxing and satisfying.Modding support greatly extends the shelf life and fun of the game, even with its qurks.Improvements: Improve the UI technicality, sometimes buttons fail to respond or work, button pressing may cause another button to be pressed and changing the game title is very awkward.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												A nice, simple and relaxing business simulation game, where you start off developing small games on your own in your basement, to releasing AAA titles as a fully fledged company. With very simple game mechanics, improve your game scores by adding game features, training your employees, managing your development focus, and match market trends to build a massive following of fans to become the most successful game developer in the world! If only it was so easy in real-life...Check out my Unobtainium (Seriously?) achievement guide herePros:+ Simple game mechanics+ Addictive gameplay+ Relaxing+ Workshop support for mods and more!+ Some nice Easter Egg achievementsCons:- Score calculations can be confusing and limiting at times- Repetitive gameplayMy Score: 7/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I wasn't exactly sure what I was in for when I got this game- fortunate enough to get it on sale for free after selling holiday cards on the market - I just thought '♥♥♥♥ it'; you know?  Well, bang-for-your-buck this one really scores HIGH.  The gameplay is pretty similar to that of the 'Democracy' series (all buttons and sliders) but still somehow manages to achieve the just-one-more-turn effect that makes the 'Civilization' series so notorious.  Despite being fairly repetative, you still find yourself replaying the game several times to unlock all the genres and find the perfect combos...and get that awkward-as-hell 11/10 review for your Cop/Puzzle Adventure game...Recommended price: anything under £6.99

												One of the best tycoon/simulation games around. I can't recommend this game enough to anyone who's into such games. It's a relatively simple game, but it's pretty addicting once you get into it.You can not only make your own games (there's a variety of genres that you can mix and match to your heart's delight; even more with the Steam Workshop) but your own game consoles (even more of them too with Steam Workshop) as well. You can even make your own version of Steam in game.From a humble setting (a garage in the 1980s), this game offers you the chance to forge your own way through gaming history and I've had a blast doing exactly that.Whether full price or on sale, I wholly recommend getting this game.And Greenheart, I saw your thank you message in game. You're very welcome.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												     Game Dev Tycoon , bir oyun yapma simulasyonudur.Oyuna Eski bir bilgisayar ve kendi evimizin garajında başlıyoruz.Ama tabikide hep aynı yerde oyun yapmıyoruz.Oyuna başladığımızda belli bir miktar paramız oluyor, oyüzden hemen bir ofise geçemiyoruz.Bir ofise geçmemiz içinse 2M veya daha fazla para isteniyor.Bu miktarda bir para gözünüzü korkutmasın.Para nasıl mı kazanılıyor dersiniz ? :     Oyunda çeşitli konular ile çeşitli oyun türleri var.Bizim oyundaki amacımız ise bu ikisini güzel bir kombinasyon haline getirerek ortaya güzel bir oyun çıkarmak.Eğer doğru kombinasyonu tutturabilirseniz sıra geldi platform seçmeye , oyuna ilk başladığımızda platform olarak sadece G64 ve PC var.Hemen endişelenmeyin ! Oyunda İlerlediğinizde xBox, Playstation , Nintendo Wii ve benzeri markaların konsolları da açılıyor.Ama dediğim gibi ; İlerleyen zamanlarda... Bu platformlar yayınlandığında ise karşınıza büyük bir sorun çıkıyor,bu platformların lisansı her bir konsol için ayrı lisans satın almanız gerekiyor.(Bu arada lisans demişken bu oyun , bu oyunun yapımcısı olan GreenHearts'ın ilk oyunu olduğu için oyunda ne xBox'ın ne Nintendo'nun ne de Playstation'ın lisansı var.Ama GreenHearts telif yememek için xBox'u mBox , Nintendo'yu Ninvento , Playstation'ı ise Playsystem olarak isimlendirmişler.)şimdi gelelim oyumuzun ilk yapılış aşamasına :     1.Aşama : İlk aşamamızda motor,oynanış ve hikaye isimli 3 tane bar çıkıyor.Biz ise seçtiğimiz oyun türüne göre bu barları yukarı veya aşağı çekiyoruz.Örn :Bir simulasyon oyununda oynanış önemliyse onu yukarı doğru çekiyoruz.Tüm barları doğru koyduğunuza inanıyorsanız ''tamam'' a tıklayıp biraz beklemeniz gerekli.Çünkü tamam a tıkladıktan sonra adamınız seçtiğiniz barlara göre çalışmakta olacaktır(Merak etmeyin çok uzun sürmüyor.)     2.Aşama: Bu aşamada ise yine 3 tane bar karşımıza çıkıyor.Fakat bu barların isimleri farklı , diyaloglar , bölüm tasarımı ve yapay zeka. Yine bu barlarıda arttırıp azaltıyorsunuz.Örn: Bir aksiyon oyununda yapay zeka önemliyse onu yukarı çekin.Tüm barları ayarladığınızda yine ''tamam''a basıp bir süre adamınızın o barlara göre oyunu tasarlamasını bekliyoruz.     3.Aşama: Bu aşamadaki barlar ise , dünya tasarımı , grafik ve ses.Burada da barları yukarı veya aşşağı çekerek vericeğimiz zamanı değerlendiriyoruz.Örn :Bir aksiyon oyununda grafik önemli ise onu yukarı çekiceksiniz.Bunları ayarladıktan sonra yine ''tamam''a basıp devam ediyorsunuz.Ve oyununuz hazır ! 3.Aşamayıda yaptıktan sonra karşınıza bir ekran çıkıyor ve 2 seçenek beliriyor : Çöp kutusuna at veya oyunu yayınla.Siz oyuna yeni başladığınız için tabikide oyunu yayınla seçeneğini seçiceksiniz.Vee oyununuz yayınlandı ! Oyununuzu yayınladıktan bir ekran beliriyor sonra yaptığınız kombinasyona ve barlardaki yukarı aşağı seçimlerinize göre 4 adet oyun profesyoneli veya dergisi(artık ne diyorsanız) oyununuza 10 üzerinden bir puan veriyor.Aldığınız puanların ortalamasına göre oyununuzun satışlarıda değişiyor.Örneğin hepsinden 10 puan aldığınız bir oyunla , hepsinden 5 aldığınız oyunun satışları arasından bir hayli fark oluyor.     Oyun hakkında anlatılacak daha çok şey var fakat çok fazla şey yazdım.Oyüzden burada bitiriyorum.Eğer oyunla ilgili sorunlarınız veya bilmek istediğiniz şeyler varsa bana mesaj atarak ulaşabilirsiniz.Ve oyunu almak hakkında tereddüte düştüyseniz hiç tereddüt etmeden alın.Verdiğimiz paranın her kuruşunu hakeden bir oyun ! İncelemem hoşunuza gittiyse ve oyun hakkında ufakta olsa bir fikir edindiyseniz ne mutlu bana... İyi Oyunlar !

												This game is friggin' ADDICTING!!! I get lost for hours upon hours and it stays fun and exciting the entire time, the visuals are cute and simple but the core of this game is what makes it one of best PC games I've ever played, it truely is the pinnacle of how fancy graphics are not needed to make a perfect game. I grew up with Atari, Apple II, Commedore 64, NES, SEGA, etc.etc. so this game just pours on the nostolgia with the sounds and style plus the hilarious alternative universe gaming console lineup for you to develop on, create your own world at your own pace and develop games you always wanted or you can play it like real history, pretend you were on the ground floor of Valve, Sega, Nintendo, Sony or Microsoft, create the top games of all time and see how filthy rich you can get while having a blast + training your brain all at the same time!I have absolutely nothing bad to say about this game, instant classic and one of my all time favorite games.11/10 - it's that good!

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I struggled a lot with whether or not to recommend this game.  It is nothing that it doesn't claim to be, but that was exactly the problem for me.  Ultimately, I settled on "no" simply because there is absolutely no replay value, and the gameplay is a mindless grind-fest.Your decisions have minimal impact on the course you take through the game (short of making totally stupid decisions that bankrupt your company -- if you have half a brain, that won't ever happen).  The gameplay an hour or two into the game is exactly the same as it is in the first ten minutes.  None of the content you unlock as you progress was enough to hold my interest; they're more or less just reskins of existing content.  The endgame mechanics are nearly identical to the early game mechanics, just with more staff, more fans, and more revenue.If you like that kind of repetitive zen-ish gameplay then this game might be for you, but even at $10 I don't feel like this game is worth it.  I played it one time for a few hours, and there's nothing whatsoever that makes me want to play it again.  There are far better tycoon/simulation games more deserving of your time.

After getting to know some people in the industry, I learned that I love the industry too much to allow being a part of it to ruin me. Greenhart games, thank you for making a game that kept this "old man" up until 1am, dreaming about what it would have been like. Posted: December 2, 2013
												Every now and again a game comes along that, on the surface, looks and feels both primitive and simple. Yet, scratch away beneath that nostalgic sugar-coating, and you begin to unearth a hidden depth to the game and unlock a colossal time-sink that will occupy you for days and days. Minecraft is a good example of this phenomenon, with its retro looks and simple goal of survival. So too is Game Dev Tycoon.The premise is simple; you're a  budding game developer of the 80's, working from your garage, and all you have to do is keep making games, and therefore, money.You start out with the most basic of technology and a few topics to get you started. Over time you'll be able to create your own game engine, and create bigger and better games. Before you know it, you'll be into a proper office where you'll be able to hire staff to help you with bigger and better projects, and market your new game to create hype and therefore, sales. The game follows a fairly loose real-time-line of computer history (missing out on the Amiga though, which is nearly unforgivable!), releasing new gaming devices and technology along the way. You'll decide which platform to release to, experiment with different concepts and topics. Towards the endgame dominating the markets with your own cutting-edge technology and AAA games will be your primary goal. You can set a game to last 35 years, but you're not restricted by that. That limit is only to let you know the game isn't keeping score anymore. You'll want to carry on regardless and continue in your quest to control the world. This game is that compulsive. I have a save game that's now into it's 150th year, which with it's fanbase and regular MMO releases is bringing in over £25 billion a year!Regardless, once you've played through once, you'll want to do it again. Only this time better, and in pursuit of the fabled 11/10 review score. Which means experimenting with new topics and combos, and making sure your team are not only up to the task, but well refreshed.Staff training is just as important, too. Getting the stats up to spec of all your staff, and most importantly, yourself, is paramount. High stats unlock specializations which greatly improve your games, and are the only way to create truly successful AAA games.Graphically, you're looking at a flash game, pretty much. The only real animation you'll see is the popping of little coloured bubbles as you create a new game, complete a contract or generate research points. Again, though, the sound of the popping of coloured bubbles is instantly absorbing and before you know it, you're galavanting through the valleys of bubble-wrap therapy, and six hours have passed you by.This is a game that requires a bit of a sit-down and a few hours thrown at it in order to get to grips with the surprisingly deep game mechanics, but actively wants you to keep scratching away at the apparently nostalgic, sugar-coated surface, and discover the treasures it keeps below.For the money, I can't recommend this game enough.   85%

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a hidden gem within the indie genre, incorporating a large amount of cool and innovative features coupled wiht a bit of gaming history in the process. The game starts you off in a small garage around the year 1980 when video gaming really first began, from there you slowly begin to make games and build your reputation. You get to choose the genre of game, how much time you want to put into areas such as 'Gameplay, Graphics and Sound' and then produce it and recieve a review. Your reviews will govern how much income you generate, making too many badly recieved games will eventually cause you to go bankrupt how ever recieveing a 9 or 10 can see your profit skyrocket. As your small company grows and expands you will have the opportunity to create your own gaming engine, company marketing and even your own console. Furthermore in the later stages of the game you can hire staff and assign them certain roles which is crucial when developing later AAA Games. Game Dev Tycoon took me around 4 hours to do a complete playthrough, that is having a company worth over $400,000,000, however there is quite a large amount of replayability on offer. Overall I do believe this was a fun and innovative indie game and is well the worth $10 (or under).8/10.

There was also a lack of explanation of how some elements influenced the game.It does show a lot of potential and I they will continue working on it.However some of the shortcomings I have mentoined here. I found the game highly enjoyable with a great sense of strategy. Taking risks and dealing with failure and great successes.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is enjoyable for it's genre. While playing, you, the creator of your own game development studio needs to work your way up to the development of big titles. Starting in the 80's with limited platforms on which to create games, as time goes on you take a trip down memory lane, creating titles to be released on parody consoles that mirror those that seem like a distant memory now. As far as a tychoon game goes, this one is addictive and forces you to be mindful of the components that run your business (such as althernate ways to earn income) as well as being strategic. The hardest part of this game is knowing what genres work best on what platforms, and for what audience. It's also tough because you need to consistently research new information and techniques to further develop your marketing skills and create new engines to release your games on. While tricky at points, this game is still enjoy able and will definitely find a way to take up all your time for an evening if you're not careful.

Posted: January 29, 2014
												So recently, I went on a buying binge for Steam games, and I accidentally bought Game Dev Tycoon amongst everything. Initially, I saw my mistake as just that; a mistake and I had no intention of actually playing this game, me being a natural hater of Tycoon games. After a few days of seeing the name in my Library, I finally relented and played it. And I'm really glad I did. The fact I could make up whatever games I wanted, with whatever company I wanted, and smile smugly to myself when they racked over ten million sales, or feel disappointed when they crashed and burned. The history that has been researched for game consoles made me smile, because it tells me the developers of this game put some actual thought into their design process; a trait that seems absent these days (You know who you are). The game starts with giving you a choice of what to call your company, and what to name your character. So, me being me, I called my company "Rainbow Slot Machine" and my character "Red Reno". I had four game topics to choose from initially, and two platforms. Assuming I was in the 80s, because I didn't read the tutorial my first try, I decided to make an Action Business game called "Stock Syndrome". I was shocked, however, when my game scored a 2.25. I thought it was a good idea. Then I tried a different tactic, and made a Fantasy RPG, which people seemed to like more, giving me an 8.75. However, I was so bad at judging what types of games people would like, I eventually ran my company into the ground on the second level, with bad publishing deals and hiring too many people. And so I tried again.THIS TIME I actually read the tutorial, and I started to understand how the game worked. THIS TIME, I had seven successful franchises, two MMOs and a console, until I decided to just make bad decisions again and run my company into the ground... again.The game is a great creation in my eyes, allowing freedom of choice in every area of a game's creation, who to hire and whether or not to be a "good" game developer or an "evil" game developer (*cough* EA *unconvincing cough*). The game's art is nice, considering the type of game, and, as stated before, you can really feel the developers put some work into this. I, being a hater of most Tycoon games, am surprised I actually recommend this.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												*English Version below. Keep in mind, that I'm not that good at speaking English, but I hope it's okay for you.*Game Dev Tycoon, was mache ich nur mit dir? In Game Dev Tycoon könnt ihr die Historie der Spieleentwicklung erneut miterleben. Ihr seid ein Programmierer, der in seiner Garage beginnt, Spiele zu entwickeln, sich hocharbeitet, eigene Spiele-Engines entwickeln und schließlich eine Firma mit bis zu fünf Angestellten besitzt. Ihr könnt im LateGame auch eigene Konsolen entwerfen oder einen Online-Dienst anbieten.Ausschlaggebend für euren Erfolg ist die Qualität der Spiele, wenn sie richtig gut sind muss auch die Frequenz der Releases nicht allzu hoch sein, da ein guter Titel sehr schnell sehr viele Einnahmen bescheren kann. Das Spiel ist in einem humorvollen Stil gehalten, was auch die einfache, comichafte Grafik wiederspiegelt. Da die Entwickler von Game Dev Tycoon anscheinend nicht das Geld für Lizenzen der großen Spielehersteller bzw. Hardwarehersteller hatten, entwickelt ihr beispielsweise später im Spiel Games für die mBox oder das PlaySystem. Diese Anspielungen sind durchwegs lustig und haben mir immer wieder ein Lächeln auf die Lippen gezaubert.Doch nun zu der Core-Mechanik von Game Dev Tycoon, und diese ist der Grund, warum ich mich nicht entscheiden kann, ob es gut oder schlecht ist: die Spieleentwicklung. Der einzige Weg, ein Spiel zu entwickeln, ist, indem ihr jeweils drei Balken so verschiebt, wie es euch passt, wobei euch das Spiel nie genau sagt, was wofür zuständig ist. Wo liegt beispielsweise der unterschied zwischen Graphic und World Design? Ist beides eine "Design-Category"? Oder doch "Technical"? Auch die Reviews, die eure Spiele bekommen, geben darüber nicht wirklich Aufschluss, und ihr könnt zwar sogenannte "Game Reports" erstellen, allerdings bringen auch diese nur bedingt einen Vorteil. So wisst ihr dann zwar, dass zum Beispiel Action und Military oder Dungeon und RPG gut zusammenpasst, oder dass für eines dieser Spiele die Dialoge sehr wichtig ist, allerdings kennt ihr dennoch nicht die genaue Zusammensetzung, und so ist es manchmal fast mehr Trial&Error als Spaß.Mich persönlich haben diese Negativpunkte aber nie wirklich massiv gestört, so dass für mich das Spiel immer noch Spaß gemacht hat. Ob derartige Probleme für einen das Spiel vermiesen oder nicht, muss jeder selbst wissen.So kann ich zu guter letzt nur sagen: Wenn euch die von mir angesprochenen negativen Aspekte nicht allzu stören (ja, es klingt absurd, ein Spieleentwicklungs-spiel in dem das Spieleentwickeln die Schwachstelle ist^^), und ihr so wie ich mit den positiven so eine Freude habt, dass diese dafür aufwiegen, schaut euch Game Dev Tycoon unbedingt an. Vor allem in einem Sale ist es richtig günstig zu haben, allerdings können die ganz Enthusiastischen unter euch auch beim Normalpreis bedenkenlos zuschlagen.*****Game Dev Tycoon, what do I think of you...?In Game Dev Tycoon you can take part in the history of gaming and replay it. You are a programmer, who starts to make games in his garage, then works his way up, starts to create custom engines, and ends up having up to five employees and being one of the big players in gaming developement. In late game, you can even create your own online-device or launch your very own console.To be sucessfull, you've got to develope good games. In case you manage to make really good ones, you don't need to publish a new game every five minutes, only a few will be enough, but if you're games aren't too good... EA knows what I'm talking about. :PThe game is in a humerous and funny style, which is supported by the comic-like graphics. Another funny thing is, that the developers of Game Dev Tycoon probably hadn't had the money for licenses, so later on you develope games for consoles such as the mBox and the PlaySystem. This was something I really enjoyed.But now, let's step into the core-mechanics of Game Dev Tycoon, and this is the reason why I can'T decide wether I like the game or not, wether it's good or bad: developing games. You can only develope a game by moving the kind of bars, which represent one aspect of game-developement. But there's a problem with those, because they aren't well explained. For example: What's the difference between Graphic and World Design? Is both to put into the "Design-Topic"? Or is it the technical part? Or something totally different?Furthermore, when your game is reviewed, you don't get any more real information about what was good or bad (mainly meaning the bars). Well, you can create a game report, but they don't tell you too much either. For example, they might have you know that Action and Military or Dungeon and RPG are a good combination, or that for a certain game Dialogues are more important than for another, but they don't tell much, so in some cases it's more Trial&Error than fun.For me, the negative points haven't been too bad, so I still had fun with the game, but if you think of buying the game, you have to decide yourself. I'm not saying it's super good or super bad, it has it's qualities and shortcomings, but you'll have to decide yourself, wether it could still be fun or not.Finally, there's nothing more to say than this: If you don't care to much about the negative points (yuhurr, it's sounding absurd, a game about developing games where the game-developing part is the shortcoming^^), and you still think like you could have fun with Game Dev Tycoon, go, take a look at it. But I'd recommend buying it in one of the Steam Sales, it's pretty cheap them, but if you're really enthusiasthic, you can also go and buy it straight right now.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												What can be said about Game Dev Tycoon that has not already been said. The core gameplay of Game Dev Tycoon is similar to that of other tycoon games in the sense that you're out there trying to make a fortune, and what a better way than starting your own videogame company? You start in your garage, and watch as the game consols we grew up with pop up on the market, and develop for them. As time progresses, and you amass your fortune, you can move to larger and larger facilities, and hire more staff. Along the way, you research newer game engines, new topics, and even completly new ideas with your R&D department, such as project grid. I wont say anymore, as I dont want to spoil the entire experience, but I will say this. This is a game made by gamers, for gamers. Greenheart hit this one out of the park, and everything from the core game, to the smallest reference, is spot on, and I can definatly reccomend it as such.

Posted: February 23, 2014
												It's 2:30am, you're in your basement punching away at your keyboard on your very first game. $100 million worth of sales later and you're the new hot shot dev house!This is a neat little indie game by Greenheart Games in which you have your own game development company with the end goal of becoming the most successful company the industry has ever seen! When you start off, the types of games and genres you can make are pretty limited, however, as you progress more and more genres unlock. Earn insane sales records by mixing genres and gameplay to their most suitable platform. By the end of it you're a multi-genre/multi platform giant! This game is really neat, as not only does it offer you the freedom of creating your own video games, but it actually gives you a history lesson on the video game industry as you progress.Pick up this game to kill a few hours, and watch yourself rinsing several days on it!

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I use to not really be in to games like this.  When I heard about Game Dev Tycoon, I added it to my wishlist because I wanted to see how it was.  It finally came on sale during the Winter Sales, and along with almost 30 other games, I bought it.  It took me a while before I decided to download it, and an hour into the game, I realized it was a mistake to wait that long.  I am actually the co-writer and a voice actor of one of my friends' projects they are woking on.  I've always been interested by video games.  After starting it, I see you start with 5 genres and 4 or so types of games.  You had to do research to unlock more genres.  There was also the very immersive engine builder.  It covered soooooo many things that you would actually have had to do if you were building your own engine.  But most of all, my favorite part of this game is the extreme care and precision in following gaming history.  All of the consoles are based off of the game consoles we've actually had, along with accurate facts for each and every one of them.  While they are missing some game consoles (like the NeoGeo), the developers covered everything important.Since this is actually realistic and tailored with real gaming history, I will add that rating as well.Gaming History Friendly-9.5/10Detail of the In Game Mechanics-9.5/10Realism-8.5/10Graphics-N/A (not applicable) | N/I (not important).  Yes, this is actually one of those games where graphics don't matter.  Accordingly, I won't factor in Graphics to the final rating.Music-6/10Replay Value-9/10Overall Value-8.5Recommended buy price-$12 USD or cheaper.  Worth the price.Note: I do not recommend modding this game, though it is supported.  Beware that installing/uninstalling mods can corrupt your data.  They also really don't help enhance the game, either.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												*English Version below. Keep in mind, that I'm not that good at speaking English, but I hope it's okay for you.*Game Dev Tycoon, was mache ich nur mit dir? In Game Dev Tycoon könnt ihr die Historie der Spieleentwicklung erneut miterleben. Ihr seid ein Programmierer, der in seiner Garage beginnt, Spiele zu entwickeln, sich hocharbeitet, eigene Spiele-Engines entwickeln und schließlich eine Firma mit bis zu fünf Angestellten besitzt. Ihr könnt im LateGame auch eigene Konsolen entwerfen oder einen Online-Dienst anbieten.Ausschlaggebend für euren Erfolg ist die Qualität der Spiele, wenn sie richtig gut sind muss auch die Frequenz der Releases nicht allzu hoch sein, da ein guter Titel sehr schnell sehr viele Einnahmen bescheren kann. Das Spiel ist in einem humorvollen Stil gehalten, was auch die einfache, comichafte Grafik wiederspiegelt. Da die Entwickler von Game Dev Tycoon anscheinend nicht das Geld für Lizenzen der großen Spielehersteller bzw. Hardwarehersteller hatten, entwickelt ihr beispielsweise später im Spiel Games für die mBox oder das PlaySystem. Diese Anspielungen sind durchwegs lustig und haben mir immer wieder ein Lächeln auf die Lippen gezaubert.Doch nun zu der Core-Mechanik von Game Dev Tycoon, und diese ist der Grund, warum ich mich nicht entscheiden kann, ob es gut oder schlecht ist: die Spieleentwicklung. Der einzige Weg, ein Spiel zu entwickeln, ist, indem ihr jeweils drei Balken so verschiebt, wie es euch passt, wobei euch das Spiel nie genau sagt, was wofür zuständig ist. Wo liegt beispielsweise der unterschied zwischen Graphic und World Design? Ist beides eine "Design-Category"? Oder doch "Technical"? Auch die Reviews, die eure Spiele bekommen, geben darüber nicht wirklich Aufschluss, und ihr könnt zwar sogenannte "Game Reports" erstellen, allerdings bringen auch diese nur bedingt einen Vorteil. So wisst ihr dann zwar, dass zum Beispiel Action und Military oder Dungeon und RPG gut zusammenpasst, oder dass für eines dieser Spiele die Dialoge sehr wichtig ist, allerdings kennt ihr dennoch nicht die genaue Zusammensetzung, und so ist es manchmal fast mehr Trial&Error als Spaß.Mich persönlich haben diese Negativpunkte aber nie wirklich massiv gestört, so dass für mich das Spiel immer noch Spaß gemacht hat. Ob derartige Probleme für einen das Spiel vermiesen oder nicht, muss jeder selbst wissen.So kann ich zu guter letzt nur sagen: Wenn euch die von mir angesprochenen negativen Aspekte nicht allzu stören (ja, es klingt absurd, ein Spieleentwicklungs-spiel in dem das Spieleentwickeln die Schwachstelle ist^^), und ihr so wie ich mit den positiven so eine Freude habt, dass diese dafür aufwiegen, schaut euch Game Dev Tycoon unbedingt an. Vor allem in einem Sale ist es richtig günstig zu haben, allerdings können die ganz Enthusiastischen unter euch auch beim Normalpreis bedenkenlos zuschlagen.*****Game Dev Tycoon, what do I think of you...?In Game Dev Tycoon you can take part in the history of gaming and replay it. You are a programmer, who starts to make games in his garage, then works his way up, starts to create custom engines, and ends up having up to five employees and being one of the big players in gaming developement. In late game, you can even create your own online-device or launch your very own console.To be sucessfull, you've got to develope good games. In case you manage to make really good ones, you don't need to publish a new game every five minutes, only a few will be enough, but if you're games aren't too good... EA knows what I'm talking about. :PThe game is in a humerous and funny style, which is supported by the comic-like graphics. Another funny thing is, that the developers of Game Dev Tycoon probably hadn't had the money for licenses, so later on you develope games for consoles such as the mBox and the PlaySystem. This was something I really enjoyed.But now, let's step into the core-mechanics of Game Dev Tycoon, and this is the reason why I can'T decide wether I like the game or not, wether it's good or bad: developing games. You can only develope a game by moving the kind of bars, which represent one aspect of game-developement. But there's a problem with those, because they aren't well explained. For example: What's the difference between Graphic and World Design? Is both to put into the "Design-Topic"? Or is it the technical part? Or something totally different?Furthermore, when your game is reviewed, you don't get any more real information about what was good or bad (mainly meaning the bars). Well, you can create a game report, but they don't tell you too much either. For example, they might have you know that Action and Military or Dungeon and RPG are a good combination, or that for a certain game Dialogues are more important than for another, but they don't tell much, so in some cases it's more Trial&Error than fun.For me, the negative points haven't been too bad, so I still had fun with the game, but if you think of buying the game, you have to decide yourself. I'm not saying it's super good or super bad, it has it's qualities and shortcomings, but you'll have to decide yourself, wether it could still be fun or not.Finally, there's nothing more to say than this: If you don't care to much about the negative points (yuhurr, it's sounding absurd, a game about developing games where the game-developing part is the shortcoming^^), and you still think like you could have fun with Game Dev Tycoon, go, take a look at it. But I'd recommend buying it in one of the Steam Sales, it's pretty cheap them, but if you're really enthusiasthic, you can also go and buy it straight right now.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is one of those games that makes me wish there was a "Maybe" button in Steam reviews. It's not a bad game, but it's really not all that great. It's just that it happens to fill a very, very specific niche reasonably competently. If you've played the mobile game Game Dev Story, then you more or less know what you're in for. It's nearly exactly that game with some stuff rearranged or expanded.As biz sims go, this one is very laid back. It's not too terribly difficult, there isn't a lot to keep track of, and your goals are straight forward and repetitive. That said, if you don't mind the casual experience, what you get in return is a video game about making video games. For me, the novelty there was enough to warrant playing it. But if you're looking for a sim with any real depth, look elsewhere.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is a simple game that is far from perfect but is a good way to spend a few hours.You can develop games for consoles from the early 80's to the future which is pretty sweet.It is hard to master getting perfect ratings for your games as you will have to learn what type games work best on which console, which audience is best, and the best balance between graphics, sound and gameplay.After the games 35 year end point you can continue playing, unlocking things and perfecting your games but after that it gets boring after 40-50yrs depending on how well you're doing.It took me roughly 3 days to level up my character and employees to level 10, unlock everything and get all the achievements. It was fun and enjoyable but after the 20 hour mark it did get a bit boring and repetitive but the game is moddable and people have expanded upon and improved the game which is great for another couple of hours.Is it worth buying?that depends... if you want a simple sim to keep you entertained for a weekend then yes.if you want something that will give you months of enjoyment you're probably best trying another game.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												This game is a truly amazing game for it's value, with lots of vanilla gameplay (8 hours) and hours more of modding and improving the game. While you might be disappointed by the lackluster gameplay towards the very end, the beginning and middle ramp up in difficulty easily and fluidly, and you never feel like you don't understand what's going on, but you do sometimes not know what to do.Will you sabotage your competitior for money, but risk the potential of it coming back to you? Or will you decide to keep your current outdated security system, and leave your building at risk?Though the game has lots of fun decisions and aspect, it also has a few issues as I've mentioned. Firstly, there's only about 3 generic soundtracks playing throughout the entire game and secondly the game at the end of it's scenarios and natural gameplay becomes unbelievably boring vanilla, and mods only fix this slightly.In all, Game Dev Tycoon is an interesting change from the average FPS or strategy. I feel like it's a natural evolution of the F2P games on mobile, with much more rewards and much less waiting, in exchange for less time to play.My score: 7.5/10
