Posted: December 29, 2014
												This is one of my FAVORITE business sim games. This isn't perfect, but for a first outing from this studio, they did a phenominal job. Pros: Rewarding entrepreneurship sim. It feels great to hire the right people and see your products get great reviews year after year. In some very important ways, this is the best entrepreneurship simulator on the market. It's challenging. I got cocky and without realizing it began bankrupting my first company. The second time around I hired more slowly and trained my people and kept a constant reserve of chash to keep my boat afloat but there were still times when my account would go from being millions of dollars in the black to being more than 100k in the red. They do a good job of rewarding ethical opperators. Your fans will thank you for making a product with them in mind and not being like some of the more infamous large studios in the real world. (not to mention any names *Cough* EA *Cough*)Cons:The years are too short and the time between consol generations are inconsistant. I would like to see this game take a solid 25 or more real world hours to go through the 35 in game years. The art is inconsistent (look at the art for the game sphere vs the playsystem) I would love to see them come out with a longer, more polished and balanced sequel. I know I'll support it.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												I had submitted a review for Game Dev Tycoon more than a year ago. The game has gone through a lot of changes, and I have learned a lot more while I have kept playing it. For this reason, I have decided to update my review and make it more extended.First of all, I think Game Dev Tycoon will keep expanding and growing, it's a game that shows a lot of potential. Since Game Dev Tycoon implemented Steam Workshop it has evolved a lot, especially via the ability to create and utilize mods to modify the average experience. I believe Game Dev Tycoon will continue to evolve, progress and attract more people to buy it over time because of Steam Workshop and updates done by the developers.To continue, I wish to say this was Greenheart Games' first game. Seriously, these people deserve a round of applause! This is a truly amazing game that most companies can't pull off, especially as their first game. I am excited to see what Greenheart comes up with in the future; I know it'll be just as great as Game Dev Tycoon, perhaps even greater! Following these statements, I would also like to point out that I haven't noticed a single bug in this whole game, and I've played it a lot! The game runs very smoothly in my computer and all of its artwork is stunningly beautiful! All the consoles, all the names, all news, it is noticable a massive amount of effort was put into each of these aspects to make the game as marvelous as it is.Finally, I would like to higlight tha fact this game is super easy to understand! You can be a gamer, as you may be a non-gamer and enjoy this game. That's why I recommend this game to each and every Steam player; especially newcomers who haven't bought a single game. I am sure Game Dev Tycoon will continue to be a massive success, like it has been so far.

Posted: January 17, 2015
												Just finished my first playthrough and wow, what a great game! Had me totally hooked, couldn't stop playing.Pros:The mechanics are deep, but not complex to the point where it becomes a riddle. You will gradually get the gist of every genre, which does make the game easier, but the addition of different expansions and resources does shake up things a bit.  It gives you a nice sense of progression as you make more and more hit games.Cons (more like things I'd like to see in a sequel):Some things bothered me during my playthrough, mainly the way it deals with sequels. If you make a sequel of a hit game without doing something else first the game punishes you. There is no way of knowing the size a game series get, every game sort of has its own reception, there is no sense of franchise. Even the hype meter doesn't go wild when you make a sequel to a high selling, beloved game. I'd like to see fans claiming for sequels of your hit franchises, absurd hype and stuff like that, maybe investors claiming for sequels. Something that lets you know you've created a huge franchise and allows you to see the effect it has on the market and in your company. Still on that topic, the game history menu is really simple and never conveys to you, in a macro sense, your body of work. It should be divided, again, into franchises, so you could easily compare how every installment did. I'd also like to see some variety on the reviews of your games and maybe a monthly bulletin with news and articles about your company. Text wise, the game is just really poor, you really have to fill in the blanks with your imagination.Most of my criticism about the game falls into what it didn't do, which I know it's unfair, but I was enjoying my playthrough so much that I really missed these features. I had to come to the point of creating a notepad file where I divided all my games in franchises with its statistics so I could have that macro point of view and could decide better which franchises to keep making games for. But besides all that, it's still a great, charming game. I totally recommend it even at full price. It's just a great little experience. Overall, 8/10Awesome little game!

Posted: September 18, 2014
												This is a fantastic game that'll keep you coming back for more as you try to prove yourself in the competetive Game Industry and bring your company to fame and fortune.It starts you off with the simple premise that you are a fledgling Game Developer trying to make a name for yourself in the still infantile Gaming World back in the 1980s. From there on out you have to use your limited budget to try and develop games, grow your fanbase, and hopefully move your company out of your parents garage.The gameplay is rather simple and user-friendly which is fantastic for the beginning player but can get a tad tedious once you're on your 7th or 8th run through of the game, that's not to say it makes the game less enjoyable but it would have definitely been a plus if the game let you get a little more hands-on at points. As the game progresses you get to choose which consoles you want to purchase a developing license for, as well as create new game engines as new technology becomes available to you. Careful portioning of your budget is vital to gameplay and a rash spender will soon find themselves bankrupt and bought out.The game is incredibly simple but has a fun, addictive quality that certainly kept me playing for a good long while and I'm sure that most of you will enjoy as well!

Posted: August 17, 2014
												I enjoyed this game a lot. BUT, and for a "tycoon/sim" type game this is a huge BUT. You can't change the speed at which time flows. 8 hours of game play and 35 Years later (if you don't go bancrupt) and the game is over, technically. I would have loved to have been able to slow the time down because there are lots of things to do in the game but as soon as you hit year 35 and the game tells you that you did a good job, well done, it doesn't feel like it's worth continuing anymore just to make further technical achievements, but you can continue, you can keep going even though you shouldn't be able to live that long (achievement for worlds oldest game developer?).Anyway. Had the game not run at lightening speed throughout I would say this game is really, really awesome. Sadly that's not the case, It's not quite perfect but I would recommend it - even if you can finish the 35 Years in one day if you were so inclined.

Posted: December 16, 2014
												The more I play this game, the more I suspect that the devs wanted to preach a message, not make a game.That message? "Mainstream is bad, indie is good." Just try making a game that fits what's popular. Simulation games are popular? Every simulation game you make will get an average score of 4 or less.It goes beyond that, though, as every random event seems to cater to what the devs believe, regardless of realism.Example: People are making fan games using the assets you put the time and money into creating? Sending a cease and desist makes you lose fans, letting them be gets you more fans, no other consequences in either case.Another: People are pirating your games. Suing them costs you fans, asking them to stop without even bringing up the idea of legal action gains fans, no other consequences.Yes, that's right, NOT defending your intellectual property is the right choice.Then there's the punishment for hyping your game in a random event. The punishment? The game is essentially guaranteed to flop and you will lose a LOT of fans. Regardless of the quality of the game. Because HOW DARE a developer be enthusiastic and want to drum up interest about a game they poured hundreds of thousands of dollars and months of their life into creating, right?So to the creators of Game Dev Tycoon, I say: Good first attempt, but I suggest that the next time you try making a game that's supposed to be an entertaining simulation of reality, you step out of your fantasy world first.And to would be customers: The game is an esoteric mess, because it's running on its own brand of logic. If you think like the devs, you win. If you don't, you lose. And frankly, the fan made mods are better than the base game. Pass this one unless you really love this sort of game, but even then I'd suggest waiting for a sale.

Posted: September 8, 2013
												Make my own game company? HELL YEAH!! This game is great for those who want to start in game design, people who love tycoon games, or people who just like games in general. The game is easy to understand, gives you a bit of chance and exploration by letting you select what demographic, system, topic, genre, how much time will be spent on certain items, and what will be shirked a bit. Also, the slight changes in the game are almost hilarious. If you get this game, try to spot the Half-Life reference. Hint: it is in one of the offices you get.

												Yep.I've played enough to make a reviewLet's start.Game Dev Tycoon is a game about developing games(like the title implies);You start in a garage with only guy,and then climb all the way up to the top.There isn't much to say about the game....so let's the positive and negative points of the gamePositive-You can unselash your imagination while making the titles;-There are a plenty of combinations;-There are nice easter eggs and parodies;-The interface is simple and works well;Negative-Lack some content(DLC for normal games,more consoles)-Unlogical details(per example:you do everyone fantasy rpg and the suddenly turns it into a adventure like game for mature audience in the next sequel/in what world super famicom is average with rpg and casual titles?)-Lack of soundtrackSorry if i mispelled something.....and......i hope this review helped you!Final Score85/100

Posted: June 21, 2015
												This is an interesting business sim where you manage your own games company throughout various stages of industry development. While it may not be as detailled as other sim games, it makes up for it in the tone and graphics. It's just a bit of fun, making up names for games, choosing their genre and platform, then moving around sliders to find the best aspects to focus on for each development stage. After it's complete, the game is then graded and in comes your cash. Throughout the game your office improves and you hire more employers until you hit modern day. One thing that brings it down slightly is the re-play value, as once you've got to modern day, you simply start again. However, you can choose to save all of the data you gathered from your first play-through about genres and which works best together/with audiences etc etc which means you're not necessarily covering old ground and you have more room to try things you didn't do first time round. This mostly makes up for it, but I still needed a good break between play-throughs. Overall, though, a great game thats just a little bit of fun. 9/10

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Não tem gráficos excelentes, não tem cutscenes nem jogabilidade dignas de registo. É um Tycoon simples. Mas... tão bem estruturado. É uma espécie de história da indústria dos videojogos, desde as primeiras máquinas às consolas e PCs topos de gama da actualidade. O tipo de jogos a desenvolver, a sua temática, o motor de jogo, o tipo de som, história, inteligência artificial, etc, etc... todos os pequenos pormenores acabam por entrar, de uma maneira ou de outra, no jogo. E, claro, há tipos de jogos que combinam com determinado tema e outros que funcionam de forma desastrosa. Não se faz um simulador de música, nem um RPG de corridas de carros. Há que acertar na escolha dos jogos a desenvolver e depois no tempo atribuído às diversas fases do seu desenvolvimento. Envolvente, e interessante, capaz de nos manter agarrados a jogar durante bastante tempo.É um excelente jogo casual, que surpreende pela positiva e entretém durante horas.

Posted: September 18, 2013
												One of the best tycoon games I've ever played. The game is well-worth your money--it's too easy to lose yourself in the game and forget what time it is--and there's something constantly happening, so you're always trying to improve, whether through making games, research, or training. There's a lot of shoutouts to gaming culture as well, and most importantly, it's just a lot of fun to play. My only complaints are that sometimes the game moves too fast, and you don't get to do as much as you'd like (and if you know which consoles have done well and which have done poorly, you won't get much time to make games for those), but if you like tycoon games, then you should definitely buy this one.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												A new interesting type of game that we haven't seen much of before. It brings you back to the days when gaming was just a baby and lets you play as a game developer. You can make any type of game, from a Call of Duty type Military Action game to a Skyrim type Medieval RPG. You can create small games and big AAA titles. You start by working as a newbie in your garage, to owning a big office with other developers. You choose what element(s) to focus your game development on, and if you focus on the right things for the right game you will end up with a 10/10 game. Heck, you can even get 11/10 if your game is that good.Create your own game engine and research new topics and engine parts.Amazing game 9/10.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Have you ever wanted to know what it felt like to be a keyboard warrior from the 80s?  Well get ready to get your underwear pulled over your head, because Game Dev Tycoon is going to do just that. Pull your underwear over your head.  Game Dev Tycoon takes you through the decades of gaming, letting you be that lone programmer in his mom's basement making games, instead of getting a real job.  Choose between genres, different gaming aspects, and decide what you want to focus on during development.  After the game is released, you can find out that, yes, d00m 1/2 didn't sell well.  I wonder whyPros:Game launchesFor a game about making games, it's pretty coolOnce I upgraded to an ofice with employees, I made them all asian and called them AlI was able to make a game on the commodore, knowing it was going to fail, so I guess that's my faultCons:During later parts in the game where lots of things are happening on screen, game can lag on certain systemsLate game is boring and repetitive.  In fact, just stay away from late game and enjoy the jouney, it's the best partThere is an algorithm to the game, once you discover it the game is kinda easyNintendo contacts are expensive as f**kI can bribe my employees to work 24/7, which is niceConclusion:Knowing you, you are just going to create a parody of every game in existance, and then watch it fail, and wonder why a detective RPG with a focus on story didn't work.

Posted: January 29, 2014
												So recently, I went on a buying binge for Steam games, and I accidentally bought Game Dev Tycoon amongst everything. Initially, I saw my mistake as just that; a mistake and I had no intention of actually playing this game, me being a natural hater of Tycoon games. After a few days of seeing the name in my Library, I finally relented and played it. And I'm really glad I did. The fact I could make up whatever games I wanted, with whatever company I wanted, and smile smugly to myself when they racked over ten million sales, or feel disappointed when they crashed and burned. The history that has been researched for game consoles made me smile, because it tells me the developers of this game put some actual thought into their design process; a trait that seems absent these days (You know who you are). The game starts with giving you a choice of what to call your company, and what to name your character. So, me being me, I called my company "Rainbow Slot Machine" and my character "Red Reno". I had four game topics to choose from initially, and two platforms. Assuming I was in the 80s, because I didn't read the tutorial my first try, I decided to make an Action Business game called "Stock Syndrome". I was shocked, however, when my game scored a 2.25. I thought it was a good idea. Then I tried a different tactic, and made a Fantasy RPG, which people seemed to like more, giving me an 8.75. However, I was so bad at judging what types of games people would like, I eventually ran my company into the ground on the second level, with bad publishing deals and hiring too many people. And so I tried again.THIS TIME I actually read the tutorial, and I started to understand how the game worked. THIS TIME, I had seven successful franchises, two MMOs and a console, until I decided to just make bad decisions again and run my company into the ground... again.The game is a great creation in my eyes, allowing freedom of choice in every area of a game's creation, who to hire and whether or not to be a "good" game developer or an "evil" game developer (*cough* EA *unconvincing cough*). The game's art is nice, considering the type of game, and, as stated before, you can really feel the developers put some work into this. I, being a hater of most Tycoon games, am surprised I actually recommend this.

Posted: April 19, 2014
												Ever thought you knew everything about games the funding the hard work and telling other what to focus on is the name of the game. You start out solo as a freelancer and thus cant make your AAA games early on you need to recruit others howver you cant do that in the tutorial (since you are ecantially making games ain your basement to start) you do eventually upgrade to skyscaper and get to make the games you dreamed of (well since its a simulation game like sim city its not like you need to do everything yourself)Ok hows the gameplay? Well first you get 4 random topics (like horror, mystery, etc) then you pick a genre then you have to go though the enire process of making the game from beginning to end its automatic however you have to distrube your funds and effort to different things in order for your game to work. For example RPG dont need high quality music you need to focus on gameplay and story nearly 100%, however a dancing game its a very bad idea to ignore music you are asking for the game to take your money. you must spend research points to unlock more (which is rencondmended)The object of the game like I said above build an empire starting in the 80s (yes the 80s and see the entire gaming intrustry evolve around you) in 1992 the snes comes out, in 1996 the n64 comes out by then are you good enough to make games for that system?  Its not easy you lose money every week but you can gain massive money back if you get a blockbuster. Its a good idea to memorize what happened in real life will you invest in the sega cd or the dreamcast uh....The sad part is every event happens in the same order on every playthough but you can try to make different games to see how it goes one game you can try lots of RPGs another go for more Action games its all up to you.The game uses a rating system remember gamespot and ign? well they are all in game yes with pardoyed names but every time you make a game and delete all the bugs (its a bad idea not too) they rate you depending on where you put the focus on the most. Also they take into effect the system you publisjhed on (they are graphic you know if you dont keep up with the times they will destroy you with their rating of 1-3/10 ouch >_>) Trying to please the pro gamers is very hard and part of the fun getting a perfect score is challenging and there are so many factors that can lower your score. Overall it makes the game much better too..Ok some game hints since this is a very hard game and you probably wont make it to the end on a 1st playthough. First you need to figure out what kinda game you want to make (dont do same the types of genre in a row however do keep focusing on that since you can level up in that style <for example doing lots of RPG skyrockets your story, world building, and dialogue exp bar a lot while doing lots of Action skyrocket your graphics, gameplay, and level design exp bars>) remember once you unlock sequel this is a huge opurtunity to do it since if its a sequel to a 10/10 you did earlier but with better graphics/sound/ and features the reviewers are going to love it and you gain lots of hype since the gamers know that you are making a game to a game they loved in the past.Also another mistake beginners make is recruiting way too good employees dont go for the best of the employee you do pay them all by the month (in addion to rent costs) starting with low skilled employees and then training then over time allows the costs to remain reasonable and overall make sense in real life (no newbie company hires top tier employees they cant afford them but the employees that stay with the company for a long time gets better and can even surpass the so called great employees that demand crazy monthy prices.Also another mistake beginners make is not make games for publishers until they get a fanbase (usually around 100k fans is a good number to start making your own games without help) when you are making games for other companies like Nintendo, tecmo, and many others. You only get a % of the money but your fans skyrocket really its much better in the long run so ya...once you move out of the basement its best to work for others for a while to get the fans to know you.since the quality of the games is on your employee skill levels you should train them until they are in the 500's in design,tech, and reseasch.  With stats that high they can specialze which allows you to make even better games. Once you get 6 employees spend the time to get employees with over 700 in either tech or design (this is the only time you should hire top tier employees if you need a specialist asap and you can afford his outragous monthy price) and pay to make him a specilist (which is 200 research points and a million dollars and 3-6 weeks training) they will pay off in the long run once someone has 700 design (or you hire him) and you pay for the training you unlock the design area where the final two graphic upgrades and otehr amazing upgrades are. a 700 tech that you pay the price upgrading him can unlock the area where you can make your own gaming system which will be much better then even the playstation 5, xbox1, and wii u yes you will dominate everything once you make your own gaming console.  Some speicists require 725 tech or design <_< though.Remember the main character (you) has amazing stats 300 in everything and 0 monthy costs. Never gets tired ever. But he still can get confused (stops the bar while you scratch your head its random) Train him well hes the best character in the whole game by the end its not uncommon to have him with 600 in everything (even speed which is the most useless stat) while remaining free and has infinite stamina (no need to go on a vacation). And the best part he can specilize :D totally worth it to do that too.Ok the another hint I'll give is marketing it is really useless in the beginning (since you dont have many fans) however once you start making bigger games (esp the AAA games) you need to market or else no one will know you are working on the game and thus all your hard work and effort will be unknown. Yes marketing is great and all however the big opportuny to gain media attention is the G4 (A parody) You can choose a small,medium, or large booth once a year and this generates so much hype. Once you are a multi millionare and is making a huge game with lots of features picking the big booth will skyrocket your hype and make tons of fans to buy the game day one rather then wait. Yes you will get the money you spent on marketing back if you do a good job.Last hint If you get a 10/10 game and you see the words the other publishers are giving jealous looks the pro gamers from then on will lower your overall score. Yes they are comparing all your future games to that masterpiece it can ruin the rest of your game. A good tip is dont go for your magnum opus too early or else the reviewers will expect too much from you and kill your score on the next game. Since the game lasts 35 years on an avg playthough go for the best of the best nearing the end.The biggest component is your graphics always keep that up to date and make new engines to run them (you need a design specialist with 700 design points and pay the requirement for the upgrade) to get the final two upgrades for graphics with the final one being holographic technology which is really cool. Overall its a great game little short but at only $10 you get to expierence the gaming world from a game maker pov from the 1980 all the way to 2015 (yes the future) once it reaches that the games over your high score is tallyed and the game ends...on a first play though getting straght 10/10 ratings from all the pro reviewers is really a pain in the neck but its so rewarding once you finally see the 11/10 and the AAA badge for making a masterpiece game. OR if you're adventerious try to make an MMO without getting a game over that is very hard to pull off...

Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game is something else. I'm not a gamer who really enjoys "Tycoon" style games, The Sims/Sim City, or anything of that ilk. I bought this game because it was on sale, I love games and the idea of making them and it had a lot of people surprised. So I started it up not sure what to expect and I fell in love with it.It's what I'd call Simulation lite in that it's not super in depth with the customization choices, but it is enough so to make it fun and interesting. You basically follow the exact path of the game industry from the C64 on. You start out only being able to dev simple text based rpgs or 2d Space Sims, but quickly enter the "Console Generation" as Nintendo and Sega enter the scene. You'll have to pay licensing costs, but you'll need to in order to make your company a success and get out of the dying C64 market. You need to maintain a steady streak of sales in order to support your next break away hit so that hopefully it won't just be you in your garage anymore. I started out just wanting to see what it was all about, but I got sucked in. I went from, "I'll just make one game and see what it's all about..." to "Just one more..." to "Okay. What will my sixth game be about? I need cash!" It is one of the simplest games you'll play, but done in such a way that you can't help be enjoy the hell out of it.I'm a gamer who plays just about anything, but I focus on RPGs, FPS, Action/Adventure, etc. Even though I don't generally enjoy simulation games, this one is so playable and enjoyable, I don't think it really matters what style of games you enjoy most. It has something for just about everyone.And to the Devs: You are very welcome for the support! =D You people have a bright future if you keep making engrossing little titles like this. Can't wait to see what you do next.

Posted: December 17, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon is a neat little simulator. The main part of the game focuses on 35 years of gaming history and important console releases (They don't have the licenses for the real names, but it's easy to work out). You start out in your garage developing games on your computer, once you have enough money you can move into an office, start to hire staff, and in time you can even get your own R&D lab.The acutal 'developing' of the games is fairly straight forward, you start with a small list of topics (fantasy, sci-fi, horror, racing etc...) more of which can be unlocked via research. Once you've picked a topic you choose a genre, there's 5 to choose from, you choose which system to develop the game for, to start off and later on once you've started building your own game engines, you can pick which engines to build on too, oh; you can also choose the 'audience' for a game too; Young, Everybody, Mature.Once you've chosen all the above, the actual development is divided into three sections. Each section has Three sliders that have different things connected to them, things like; World Design, Engine, Graphics, Sound etc... Set the sliders to what you think makes that particular game good, and there you go game made! Certain combinations of topic/genre/audience can work brilliantly in your favour to sell more copies, but on the other hand it can also lead to some absolute stinkers too. After you're game is complete and just before it's released you get a quick run down of experienced gained, and then on to the dreaded games review, which actually reflect how well the game will sell, so the reviewers pan the game you won't shift many units, likewise if it gets glowing reviews you're sure to make a good amount of money. Rinse and repeat until you game your own gaming empire. After a couple of releases you can start to research better graphics, sounds, AI, better story lines etc...The graphics and sounds aren't ground-breaking, but being a simulation of sorts, then they aren't going to be. I've left a couple of things out of this review as I'm sure you'll want a couple of surprises but; All in all Game Dev Tycoon is a nice fun little game, easy to get a grasp upon. The price asked for the game is definitely worth the money as there's hours and hours worth of play.

Posted: December 16, 2014
												The more I play this game, the more I suspect that the devs wanted to preach a message, not make a game.That message? "Mainstream is bad, indie is good." Just try making a game that fits what's popular. Simulation games are popular? Every simulation game you make will get an average score of 4 or less.It goes beyond that, though, as every random event seems to cater to what the devs believe, regardless of realism.Example: People are making fan games using the assets you put the time and money into creating? Sending a cease and desist makes you lose fans, letting them be gets you more fans, no other consequences in either case.Another: People are pirating your games. Suing them costs you fans, asking them to stop without even bringing up the idea of legal action gains fans, no other consequences.Yes, that's right, NOT defending your intellectual property is the right choice.Then there's the punishment for hyping your game in a random event. The punishment? The game is essentially guaranteed to flop and you will lose a LOT of fans. Regardless of the quality of the game. Because HOW DARE a developer be enthusiastic and want to drum up interest about a game they poured hundreds of thousands of dollars and months of their life into creating, right?So to the creators of Game Dev Tycoon, I say: Good first attempt, but I suggest that the next time you try making a game that's supposed to be an entertaining simulation of reality, you step out of your fantasy world first.And to would be customers: The game is an esoteric mess, because it's running on its own brand of logic. If you think like the devs, you win. If you don't, you lose. And frankly, the fan made mods are better than the base game. Pass this one unless you really love this sort of game, but even then I'd suggest waiting for a sale.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												This is an interesting business sim where you manage your own games company throughout various stages of industry development. While it may not be as detailled as other sim games, it makes up for it in the tone and graphics. It's just a bit of fun, making up names for games, choosing their genre and platform, then moving around sliders to find the best aspects to focus on for each development stage. After it's complete, the game is then graded and in comes your cash. Throughout the game your office improves and you hire more employers until you hit modern day. One thing that brings it down slightly is the re-play value, as once you've got to modern day, you simply start again. However, you can choose to save all of the data you gathered from your first play-through about genres and which works best together/with audiences etc etc which means you're not necessarily covering old ground and you have more room to try things you didn't do first time round. This mostly makes up for it, but I still needed a good break between play-throughs. Overall, though, a great game thats just a little bit of fun. 9/10

Posted: April 8, 2014
												As someone who honestly didn't like tycoon games or anything like them, this game was full of nonstop fun mixed in with a bunch of laughs. I began watching people play this game and just simply having fun watching them play it and desperately wishing I could control what they were doing. I decided to get it. Sometimes you can catch this game on sale for $5 but the $9.99 is worth every penny. I'm finishing up my second playthrough of it now. If you aren't a believer, just watch someone play this game like I did. Find someone on Twitch or YouTube giving it a go and (if they have some entertainment value) get sucked into their adventures of the gaming industry. This game starts you fresh in a garage as a 1-man-team creating your own games back when it all first began. You journey through the years gaining more technology, more people, better equipment, and much more to advance into what we play and do today. There's so much to do which makes your first few playthroughs completely different. Your first go with this game will be you learning a lot of what you can do and then with that knowledge you can have even more fun on another go. The timeline on this game is pretty much spot on, you even get to witness the break-up of Sony and Nintendo and begin making games for the PlayStation (or PlaySystem as it is called in this game due to copyright) when it drops. This game came out before XBox One and PS4 did so of course once you get around that time there is a bit of make-believe but I think they did good with it. This game doesn't just end at the current stage of gaming. It goes on a bit longer and allows you to eventually make your own consoles and your own games for your consoles. Before I go on and on and give too much away... JUST GET THE GAME! You shouldn't regret it.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												What can be said about Game Dev Tycoon that has not already been said. The core gameplay of Game Dev Tycoon is similar to that of other tycoon games in the sense that you're out there trying to make a fortune, and what a better way than starting your own videogame company? You start in your garage, and watch as the game consols we grew up with pop up on the market, and develop for them. As time progresses, and you amass your fortune, you can move to larger and larger facilities, and hire more staff. Along the way, you research newer game engines, new topics, and even completly new ideas with your R&D department, such as project grid. I wont say anymore, as I dont want to spoil the entire experience, but I will say this. This is a game made by gamers, for gamers. Greenheart hit this one out of the park, and everything from the core game, to the smallest reference, is spot on, and I can definatly reccomend it as such.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												Game Dev Tycoon is a tycoon strategy game where you create your own game development company. You start as a guy/gal working out of a cramped garage in the 80's and as you create popular games you'll gradually grow until you have enough money for a new premises as well as the option to hire employees. As you continue to grow you'll be able to make bigger, better games, research new technology to gain an advantage, create your own MMOs and even create your own powerful game engines.

Posted: June 4, 2015
												Game Dev Tycoon on the surface seems like a dull experience. Explain the nuts and bolts of this game out loud and you may think this can't be enjoyable. You would be wrong.Game Dev Tycoon stimulates your imagination by letting you fill in the blanks. In the game, you are a game dev (duh) starting out in the garage at the beginning of home video games. The game follows 35 years of history and goes a bit past present day with all of the names of the real life game companies replaced with psuedonyms. It's your task to create games for the different consoles over time while developing your skills and eventually growing your company out of the garage and into a sweet office building where you'll be faced with new challenges managing your staff. You never see the games you make; you come up with the title, decide the genre, console and prioritize what aspects of the games will be worked on. It sounds kind of meh right? But I've spent hours imagining what the games I came up with looked like and  how the cover art must have looked. It's like reading a book, where theatre of your mind is doing a lot of the heavy lifting.  Game Dev Tycoon is a great title for any fan of video game history and is reasonably priced. If you're still unsure check out Videogame Dunkey's video review. That's what convinced me that I would like this title. For ten bucks, there enough here to justify the price tag. If you disagree, pick it up on sale.

Posted: December 16, 2014
												The more I play this game, the more I suspect that the devs wanted to preach a message, not make a game.That message? "Mainstream is bad, indie is good." Just try making a game that fits what's popular. Simulation games are popular? Every simulation game you make will get an average score of 4 or less.It goes beyond that, though, as every random event seems to cater to what the devs believe, regardless of realism.Example: People are making fan games using the assets you put the time and money into creating? Sending a cease and desist makes you lose fans, letting them be gets you more fans, no other consequences in either case.Another: People are pirating your games. Suing them costs you fans, asking them to stop without even bringing up the idea of legal action gains fans, no other consequences.Yes, that's right, NOT defending your intellectual property is the right choice.Then there's the punishment for hyping your game in a random event. The punishment? The game is essentially guaranteed to flop and you will lose a LOT of fans. Regardless of the quality of the game. Because HOW DARE a developer be enthusiastic and want to drum up interest about a game they poured hundreds of thousands of dollars and months of their life into creating, right?So to the creators of Game Dev Tycoon, I say: Good first attempt, but I suggest that the next time you try making a game that's supposed to be an entertaining simulation of reality, you step out of your fantasy world first.And to would be customers: The game is an esoteric mess, because it's running on its own brand of logic. If you think like the devs, you win. If you don't, you lose. And frankly, the fan made mods are better than the base game. Pass this one unless you really love this sort of game, but even then I'd suggest waiting for a sale.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												I liked this game very much. I will give it a 8/10.The story reminds me of the life of Bill Gates. You start with a "buisiness" in your garage and try to develope new games. Every game walks through 3 stages and in every one you need to decide which part of the game should be emphasised in the development, like graphics, sounds or story. For the different genres and settings there are different parts important. After yopur first game, which normaly fails, you can analyse it and therefor learn what went good and what went wrong, e.g. that the K.I. is important for a strategie game.With this imformation you develop the next one, and the next one, ....The Graphics of the game are not the best, but good enough for the idea of the game. It was fun to play and there are several ways to play it. For me the only minuses are the short real-time in which the game-time evolves and the kind of repetitive playstile due to it. Within a certain time, there are new consols etc. But you cannot use all of them, because the time between the consol generations are too short in game time. This leads to a certain pattern for your playstyle you choosed at the beginning. So an option to play a "marathon" like game would be nice.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												I had submitted a review for Game Dev Tycoon more than a year ago. The game has gone through a lot of changes, and I have learned a lot more while I have kept playing it. For this reason, I have decided to update my review and make it more extended.First of all, I think Game Dev Tycoon will keep expanding and growing, it's a game that shows a lot of potential. Since Game Dev Tycoon implemented Steam Workshop it has evolved a lot, especially via the ability to create and utilize mods to modify the average experience. I believe Game Dev Tycoon will continue to evolve, progress and attract more people to buy it over time because of Steam Workshop and updates done by the developers.To continue, I wish to say this was Greenheart Games' first game. Seriously, these people deserve a round of applause! This is a truly amazing game that most companies can't pull off, especially as their first game. I am excited to see what Greenheart comes up with in the future; I know it'll be just as great as Game Dev Tycoon, perhaps even greater! Following these statements, I would also like to point out that I haven't noticed a single bug in this whole game, and I've played it a lot! The game runs very smoothly in my computer and all of its artwork is stunningly beautiful! All the consoles, all the names, all news, it is noticable a massive amount of effort was put into each of these aspects to make the game as marvelous as it is.Finally, I would like to higlight tha fact this game is super easy to understand! You can be a gamer, as you may be a non-gamer and enjoy this game. That's why I recommend this game to each and every Steam player; especially newcomers who haven't bought a single game. I am sure Game Dev Tycoon will continue to be a massive success, like it has been so far.

Posted: June 6, 2015
												At its core, Game Dev Tycoon is a sequence-puzzle game.  When I first started playing, I became a media darling, let that get to my head, and went bankrupt less than two years later.  After a number of horrible restarts, I finally relized I had the goals all wrong.  Sure, make a boat-load of money and be successful, but underneath all that is the one thing that drives many of us to play games with Steam Achievements: GOTTAH FIND 'EM ALL!When you start a game, you begin with just a few variables: Topic, Genre, Platform.  Take a chance, put some things in the pot, see what you get.  Does your T+G+P net +++?  Or is it more like a ---?  Either way, you've just uncovered one of the sequences this game has to offer.  Do you take the money you've just made and churn out a whole bunch of TGP clones to line your pockets?  Or do you go the maverick route and try a completely different sequence?As the game progress, more variables are added to your sequence: target Audience, game-Size, and others.  Additionally, as time passes, companies will debut the very consoles that launched the gaming industry.  So, now, your sequence becomes T+G+P+A+S=???I haven't actually finished the game yet.  I keep starting over because finding all the sequences is what drives me, as opposed to making booku-bucks.The game itself is a rather simplistic take on what goes into making a game, I'm sure.  You likely don't have to research "sequels" in order to learn how to make one, you just make it.  I'm also a little disappointed that the PC platform isn't given as much love as the various consoles that pop up.  There's no mention of when the CD-ROM drive becomes available to the PC platform; the graphic of the PC just changes to include one.People who excel in strategy games like StarCraft and the Civilization franchise will find themselves quite at home here.  For people like me, who don't, this game is still enjoyable if you remove the drive to make money.  As long as you have enough to sustain yourself, just keep inputting sequence variables into the machine and see what comes out.

												I love tycoon games, and I feel like it's a genre of contemporary neglect. In light of that, Game Dev Tycoon allows us tycoon fans to breathe a sigh of relief and subdue our addiction for a bit. Although slow-paced at certain points in the game and an upgrade to its save-load mechanism could have saved me hours (and tears), it's an insanely fun game with great steam achievements, increasingly multi-faceted throughout the storyline, pedagogical and easy to get into. I can definitely recommend it for tycoon-fanatics, the game development-interested and indie game lovers alike!

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Definitely a fun and addictive game, but needs more content. You start in the 1980's making games in your garage, and as you sell more games you can expand your company. Ultimately, while you are given many genres/topics/platforms to use to make your games, Game Dev Tycoon always follows the same path of progression. Once you figure out how to consistently release high scoring games you will be able to make money consistently and gain lots of fans. Since most of the gaming devices are inspired by real world events, if you know anything about gaming history its not hard to figure out the "right" choices. There are some random events to change things up, but I find they are few and far between. It would be nice if the market would be more dynamic rather than follow static events, kind of like being able to play "what if?" in gaming history. i.e. What if the Dreamcast had a major title that drove up console sales? Would that cause Microsoft to stay out of the market instead of trying to challenge Sony? What if the game with the most hype was really bad and led to less sales for the PS2? You do get to enter the console market with your own device, but this is so late into the game that it doesn't really mean much. Other suggestions, it would be nice if there was more to the game when it comes to sales and profit. Whether you self publish, or work with a publisher the amount of money you make seems to be only determined by the review score. You can take advantage of randomly generated trends in the market to boost sales, but if you make a good game it sells well regardless. It would be interesting to have random events in the market that can negatively affect the sales of  high scoring games. Finally, the managing of employees could be more interesting. Maybe have them leave to form new studios, demand a raise, retire, happiness rating, etc. This would provide nice challenges to managing your studio besides training/replacing/send on vacation. Overall, I enjoy this game very much, but would like to see more depth to the gameplay to make the game more dynamic.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												Great game overall, well worth the $2 I paid it for it when it was on sale a while agoI rarely write reviews but this game is actually really fun to play and considering it came from an indie developer I'm very impressed.Here's a list of pros and cons.Pros Simple and easy to understand (tool tips pop up and explain most things, basic 'help' section also) Multiple consoles to develop for (pretty much all of them, missing a few smaller ones but still great) Lots of topics and genres to build for  Progress from small slummy garage to sexy building  Towards the end there is lots of do and research (the R&D towards the end is done very well) Some similarities to other dev games, but really becomes very unique towards the middle to the end (you can specialise your workers etc) Lots of other cool stuff along the wayCons (Not really negatives, just small things that could be improved) Time passes really quickly, would have been good if there was a speed slider, or if it took a little longer for the weeks to pass Your workers are skilled in development / technology but it seems to me that only 'graphics' is the only skill that utilises the technology attribute (Maybe I just don't quite understand who to assign to different tasks on medium / large games)  Sometimes its hard to see what will be successful by combining topics and genres (it does tell you it may be a good combination after you selected what you want, given you have researched it, however it would be good if you didn't have to go back and forth to select and reselect things Lots of trial and error in discovering what works, would be good to actually research into a topic to see if the market will like itOverall great game!

Posted: March 15, 2015
Enjoyable to the max!This game is a perfect example of how a simple game with no extravagant graphics, no complicated gameplay and no breathtaking story, can still be a great and enjoyable game. The logic is quite simple. You re on your own, in your garage / working station, creating your company somewhere in the late 80's, with a passion to make it to the continuously evolving gaming industry. Your only tool is your pc and your only companion is your creativity.The game progresses through the ages, following loyaly the evolution of gaming, providing you with news from the companies as to their upcoming plans for gaming and technology to support it (both on consoles and pc) as well as the current tendencies of the gaming audience (i.e. there is a current tendency for strategy games), giving you opportunities to deliver something that will appeal more and more to your growing fanbase.As you are becoming more and more successfull on what you re doing, the game allows you to "evolve", taking your company to new, bigger offices and with the potential of hiring the first members of your company's staff. Each of them can be chosen based on their specialties (design, technology etc) so that they can provide a valuable asset to what your company needs most at any given moment.But for me, it s the little details that make this game shine. As your company is getting bigger and more successfull, the game provides you with random, sort of "pop up" choices that do fit to how a gaming company can handle certain things. From fan requests to possible "foul play" on your companies side or staff requests. The decisions you make have an impact on various things. Fanbase, staff productivity, market acceptance etc etc. To sum this up (and not spoil the fun this game can deliver), if you want to take a break from "hardcore" gaming and want a casual but funny and addicting game dev simulator, I highly recommend this game. Pros:-Low system requirements-Escalating but enjoyable difficulty-Gives the potential of going in depth to it but not as a necessity-Amusing way of avoiding copyright infringements -Personalised skill development for each of your staff-Steam Workshop support-High replayability potentialCons:-Could give the player a little more insight as to what you re doing wrong or right (although you can figure out things... through "pain" :P )-Sometimes it gives you the feeling that the years go by really fast, making developing titles for particular consoles a bit pointless. Unless you re willing to keep buying licences for the next gen consoles that their companies make.Overall score: 9/10For what this game is and does, it s a gem!Personal note / tip for new playersRight now my company is in a big office, with 7 people as staff (me included) and we ve made a name in the gaming industry, being currently at the 15 spot (out of 100) in game conventions, with a 70+ million budget and still going. So my advice to you is to be, think and act like you want the real gaming companies to be. Be modest.Once you make a couple of successfull titles and see the money filling your bank account, don t go cocky. Don t start buying expensive, highly educated personel (more than you can afford), in the hope that your next title will also be a success. Or you ll be in for a surprise... Take it slow instead. Listen to your fanbase, fulfill their requests as long as they are logical and keep it like that. When you re giving an interview, don t overhype your games. Cause if you do and the game doesn t live up to the expactations, it s gonna be double the fall. Don t worry about growing your fan base. Fans will come as long as your company stays true to it s original ideals and passion for gaming.

												Welcome to Vosoros Games…Starting out in my garage I referred to my trusty notepad of game ideas and began churning out one successful game after the next.  But it’s wasn’t enough to just make games with such primitive technology, and thus I built the VGE 1 (Vosoros Games Engine 1)…or VEG as I liked to joke at times, and still do.Oh I could hear the groans of my future staff I one day hoped to hire and help me build this company up further…And so it eventually came to pass that I did outgrow my garage and did hire those staff I envisioned needing the assistance of.  Our game engine grew with the company too, subtle changes at first with the VGE 1.1, but then transforming our lives (and those of our fans) with the VGE 2 and its 3D graphics.  As we continued to innovate with our engine, so too did we continue to innovate and improve with our games.  Our skills and finance grew as our successes chained beyond our wildest dreams.About 20 years after I’d started Vosoros Games we moved into our very own building (where we still reside today), setting aside space for a future R&D Department and a Research Lab to craft our very own console when finances permitted.Sure enough, with the creation of the VGE 5, we began to build the VGS 1 (Vosoros Games System Console 1), and it was a roaring success.  As a new game engine was built, so was a new console to accommodate the latest technological and gaming innovations we bought to our ever-growing number of fans.Today, Vosoros Games is the leading company in game design and innovation with the VGE 8 (our masterpiece game engine) and the VGS 4 (our masterpiece console system that accompanies it) with its virtual reality headset.Game Dev Tycoon is a gem of a game well worth buying…’cos Vosoros Games made it!  :P

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Não tem gráficos excelentes, não tem cutscenes nem jogabilidade dignas de registo. É um Tycoon simples. Mas... tão bem estruturado. É uma espécie de história da indústria dos videojogos, desde as primeiras máquinas às consolas e PCs topos de gama da actualidade. O tipo de jogos a desenvolver, a sua temática, o motor de jogo, o tipo de som, história, inteligência artificial, etc, etc... todos os pequenos pormenores acabam por entrar, de uma maneira ou de outra, no jogo. E, claro, há tipos de jogos que combinam com determinado tema e outros que funcionam de forma desastrosa. Não se faz um simulador de música, nem um RPG de corridas de carros. Há que acertar na escolha dos jogos a desenvolver e depois no tempo atribuído às diversas fases do seu desenvolvimento. Envolvente, e interessante, capaz de nos manter agarrados a jogar durante bastante tempo.É um excelente jogo casual, que surpreende pela positiva e entretém durante horas.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												Game Dev Tycoon is one of those games that makes me wish there was a "Maybe" button in Steam reviews. It's not a bad game, but it's really not all that great. It's just that it happens to fill a very, very specific niche reasonably competently. If you've played the mobile game Game Dev Story, then you more or less know what you're in for. It's nearly exactly that game with some stuff rearranged or expanded.As biz sims go, this one is very laid back. It's not too terribly difficult, there isn't a lot to keep track of, and your goals are straight forward and repetitive. That said, if you don't mind the casual experience, what you get in return is a video game about making video games. For me, the novelty there was enough to warrant playing it. But if you're looking for a sim with any real depth, look elsewhere.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Really nice game. As an indie game dev myself I have to admit GDT gives a good first overview of what the creation of a game looks like. I did almost 8-10 games (from the begining until the end... or bankruptcy :P), to try different combination, figure out how this works, and I enjoyed evey single one. It might look like a casual game, but don't be fooled by the graphics or the animation, you'll have to learn the mecanics and improve... this is some gamer stuff. Plus, they included some nice jokes and easter eggs, I enjoyed searching for them. I love strategy and simulation games, and I warmly recommend this one if you want to have a better understanding of the job of a indie game dev.

Posted: April 24
												REVIEW------------------1- Awful | 2- Terrible | 3- Sucks | 4- Bad | 5- Meh.. | 6- Decent | 7- Good | 8- Great | 9- Amazing | 10- Outstanding------------------(Go down to Verdict for the Quick Anwser and Explanation)One of the best tycoon games out there, Game Dev Tycoon is a game with rather simple mechanics that slowly through time become more complex. As the game says, you are a Game Dev working hard to create the greatest video game development company. This game starts in the 80s with the Commodore64 all the way to New Gen PlayStation/Xbox, giving you a throwdown of gaming history. Now game mechanics, the first and most important mechanic, Game Developing. Game developing in Game Dev Tycoon is simple you choose a name, topic, genre, console, and engine, then you are greeted with 3 Development stages. In the all the stages you adjust sliders representing Game Ingredients (Gameplay, Graphics, Story, Engine, A.I, Level Design, etc.) you have to adjust the sliders based on your topic and genre this get slightly more complex later on. You can also hire staff once you move to a new office, this is when the game becomes more challanging and where the real test starts, whether or not you can become a successfull video game company.-----------------VERDICT:-----------------8.5/10 - This game is great filled with fun content but is more sutible for people with huge imagination, people who love making stories, or people who love the video game industry as a whole. If you aren't like this but still are intrested wait and see if you can get it on sale.-----------------COMMENTS:-----------------I basically lost my life with this game, 100 hours... anyways I'll go hide in a corner and think about my life desicions, see ya later folks!

Posted: June 28, 2014
												My goodness, I had no idea how hooked to this game I would be when I picked it up.  I purchased Game Dev Tycoon and a handful of other games that were on sale and I ended up trying this one first and did not stop until I had completed it.  This is hands down one of the most addictive games I have ever played, and I really hope there will be a sequel to it. Constantly trying to find the best matches to make the best games, while at the same time being confused when certain combinations did not work.  Not only is the gameplay fun and addictive, but you also get a bit of a nostalgia kick seeing all of the consoles and handhelds released throughout the years while playing through the game.  Crazy to think how much has happened in gaming since it all started.  I highly recommend this game.  While it is a casual game, any one who loves any kind of game should be able to start this up and have a good time playing it.  11/10

Posted: March 14, 2014
												Really fun game, it's a must-have for anyone who fancies progression and perfection. The casual and easy nature of the game makes it a choice for most types of gamer's and as you progress further into the game it gets more advanced depending on how far you come.It's a trial and error game, don't expect your first few rounds to be perfect, you will fail and my tip is to always experiment with different combos and also take the advice they give you. It's got plenty of replay-ability, both hidden and visible achievements and there are a number of guides out there if you get stuck.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game is something else. I'm not a gamer who really enjoys "Tycoon" style games, The Sims/Sim City, or anything of that ilk. I bought this game because it was on sale, I love games and the idea of making them and it had a lot of people surprised. So I started it up not sure what to expect and I fell in love with it.It's what I'd call Simulation lite in that it's not super in depth with the customization choices, but it is enough so to make it fun and interesting. You basically follow the exact path of the game industry from the C64 on. You start out only being able to dev simple text based rpgs or 2d Space Sims, but quickly enter the "Console Generation" as Nintendo and Sega enter the scene. You'll have to pay licensing costs, but you'll need to in order to make your company a success and get out of the dying C64 market. You need to maintain a steady streak of sales in order to support your next break away hit so that hopefully it won't just be you in your garage anymore. I started out just wanting to see what it was all about, but I got sucked in. I went from, "I'll just make one game and see what it's all about..." to "Just one more..." to "Okay. What will my sixth game be about? I need cash!" It is one of the simplest games you'll play, but done in such a way that you can't help be enjoy the hell out of it.I'm a gamer who plays just about anything, but I focus on RPGs, FPS, Action/Adventure, etc. Even though I don't generally enjoy simulation games, this one is so playable and enjoyable, I don't think it really matters what style of games you enjoy most. It has something for just about everyone.And to the Devs: You are very welcome for the support! =D You people have a bright future if you keep making engrossing little titles like this. Can't wait to see what you do next.

Posted: January 6, 2015
												Tagging Game Dev Tycoon with the labels 'Simulation', 'Indie' and 'Management' may be accurate.  After all, it is a simulation of managing a game development studio (and a surprisingly engaging one).  But, in reality, these tags don't fully do the game justice.  Like great strategy games, it places a premium on decision making without being punishingly constricting.  It has a vein of self-determination that good RPGs possess (i.e. want to become a megalithic AAA pumping machine, or see how far you can go working alone in your garage?).  It allows for flexible resource management like a good business sim should.  But, most importantly,  this is a game that possesses that just-one-more-turn factor that any good game of its ilk needs.  In this case a turn is really a development cycle, but why quibble?If someone isn't a particular fan of job/business simulators this game still has enough going for it that they're likley to find something to enjoy about it.  At full price the game definitely delivers value for money for fans of the genre.  For others, give it a shot when it's on sale and you likely won't regret it.

Posted: April 10, 2015
												Game Dev Tycoon is an interesting game to me because sometimes it seemed to make no sense and at other times made all the sense in the world. My first playthrough was a disaster waiting to happen. I invested too much, generally made quirky games for a small cult following, and bought all the technology I didn’t need just because it seemed nice. My game company, SelectoBiz, made it pretty far in the business on some titles that just so happened to do well, but slowly dwindled in sales as I created more and more cult games. I went bankrupt after shamefully trying to do casual games that cost me fans. I became a corporate slave out of desperation… and I paid for it.So, for my next company, Red Bangkok, I decided to be an indie developer. I stayed in my garage for the whole playthrough. I churned out RPGs and simulation games with varying topics. I stuck to computer games only and slowly built up fans. All my games were logical sells, with some personal ones thrown in for fun. This company was my favorite. I would pay maybe 70 thousand for a game that would bring in six million dollars and hordes of fans. I created what I wanted and answered to no one but myself. I made it to the end of the game with 800 thousand fans and around 200 million dollars – and all I had to do was sit at a computer in my garage. It’s a sad game, really. The beginning shows the wonder and innovation explode and the end shows an industry that is making sequels every year. It shows how a tenacious prospect became monotonous. Red Bangkok made no sequels and only brought in a bit of money (compared to its competitors), but it made it to the end. All SelectoBiz did is sell out and die. Sometimes all you need is a garage and a computer, not a studio and hundreds to thousands of employees. Sometimes all you need is a dream and some fresh ideas instead of a bankable property. My biggest advice would be move with your audience and staying small sometimes pays off if you have morals to adhere to. It’s all capitalism in the end, but great things can be done. Even if greatness doesn’t turn out to mean big.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												preface:  In this review, keep in mind that I am following release dates to the US-only releases of products. I am not going to include EU or JP release dates due to this games setting being in the US. With that out of the way, let's get on with the review.-Game Dev Tycoon is a indipendence medium-game developed by Greenheart Games. And let me tell you: It's fun and addictive.Game Dev Tycoon is about ''You'' being a video/PC-Game devloper in the post-1983 crash/Atari Shock and working your way up top all the way up to the year ...2018? I think.-[Let's talk about the story]The story isn't mush to talk about.It begins with the post-'83 crash were computer-games survived the disaster, Nintendo reviving  consoles in late-1985, Sega releasing GENESIS in 1989, SONY releases PS1 in late-1995 and so on.The story is abridged though, so some events have been cut-out... such as Apple in the 80/90s, Linux, SEGA Saturn, all the add-ons for the GENESIS and *Panasonics 3DO*Though the 3DO didn't do well in US and EU and is nothing in comparison to GENESIS and SNES, it deserves recognition in gaming history for selling well in Japan.-[Let's talk about the gameplay]When developing a game, you are presented with three development stages and three pillars for each development stage(total of nine pillars).You adjust the pillars  to what works and what doesn't work. Whether you want to focus a lot on gameplay or focus a little on A.I. or don't focus on the story etc.After all the three development stages are done, you then wait for reviews.If you get very bad reviews, then that's going to give you negative fans and make less money depending on the reviews and if you hyped the game before release.If you get great reviews, then you are going to make a lot of money and have a huge following. journalists and critics will mention your great feat and with recognition you will get offers from different people.Game dev Tycoon has a... sort of.. roguelike feel to it. If you mess up in the beginning and make a wrong decision then you could get a game-over.If you make 1M dollars, you then move to an office and hire more staff and make bigger games.Though I think this is a great gameplay mechanic, I still think there are a couple of ''missed opportunities'' in the gameplay that could have been in the game. Such as:-You can't make a launch title. Or/and getting an offer from SONY or Nintendo for an exclusive title.-You can't put a price on a game. -Why can't you make something viral? like spreading a rumour of a hidden room or a mythical creature or something, like GTA with big foot. Or Mortal Kombat with the blood code on SNES.-Why can't you make 2 games at the same time. one small game an a large game for example.-Why can't you make an expansion pack on a normal game? You can make an Exp. pack, but only on MMOs.-Why can't my character have a background? not all companies starter out as one guy like Bungie. Some starter out as three guys such as Blizzard....and so on. I have a mush bigger list in my head of ''missed opportunities'' with GDT. These are a few example.-[Let's talk about the Graphics]Game Dev Tycoons graphics is hand drawn animation. I like Game Dev. Tycoons graphics.-[Let's talk about the music]For a simulator that's all about developing games, the music in this game isn't really that important. Game Dev Tycoons music is relaxing and kind to your ears.-[Before I give my ''Final Score'', I would like to say something]GDT opened up my point of view of how it looks like when developing a game. Before I played GDT I thought ''Ok... developers keep saying in interviews that the reason they can't make a sequel is because it's NOT that easy'' and I am all like ''well... maybe they're just saying that because they just want to make money and don't really care about the fans''. And after I played GDT, I finally understood what developers were saying about ''It's NOT that easy''.-[Final Score]GDT is a great game... but I feel like there were a lot of missed oppertunities. But it can be forgiven because of the addicive gameplay and for being an indie-game. I didn't like that the story was abridged and your main-character was ''another avarage Joe''. That's why I give GDT a ''great'' 8.5/10 and a ''recommended'' for anybody.I can reccommend game dev. Tycoon to anybody, even casuals. Even If you're not familiar with Simulations. And also, if you have the motivation to learn and such, then GDT is for you.[Here is an idea I have for ''Greenheart Games'' if they ever make a sequel]If Greenheart Games ever make a sequel to GDT or an Exp. Pack. Then I am would like them to add those ''missed opportunities'' that I talked about in the ''gameplay''-section.I would also like the sequel/exp. pack to follow the gaming history more accurately.-...And that's my review of GDT. Peace out and have a good one.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												A lot of the reviews for Game Dev Tycoon criticize it for being a blatant rip-off of a popular game on mobile devices - having played both I agree that the game is almost entirely unoriginal.  Does it matter?  I don't think so, should no one else be allowed to make a city simulator because Maxis made SimCity first?  The fact is this game is a lot of fun.PROS:-Good graphics.  Really pretty.  Not going to max out your gpu, but the cartooney style looks nice-Sound.  Its hard to explain but the music and all the little sound effects are really pleasant.  It'll keep you from getting fatigued.-Re-playability.  You might put in say 10 or 20 hours and feel like you have done it all, but like other sims you should be able to come back at a later date and have lots of fun all over again.CONS:-Some of the genre/topics don't work when they should.  Like Werewolf and RPG is a terrible combo - Why?  Ever heard of "Wolf Among Us?"-The game isn't very random, you could basically play THE EXACT same strategy and turn of events each play through and have the same outcome-The whole game is based on your title's scores.  The scores are based upon your previous scores.  I really don't like this, by the end of the game it becomes harder and harder to get titles earning 10/10 marks.  In other words, to get a second 10/10 game it has to be better than the previous 10/10 game.Overall - this game is really fun and I definitely recommend it to sim fans of any type.

Constantly trying to find the best matches to make the best games, while at the same time being confused when certain combinations did not work. Crazy to think how much has happened in gaming since it all started.  I highly recommend this game.  While it is a casual game, any one who loves any kind of game should be able to start this up and have a good time playing it.  11/10

Posted: September 22, 2013
												Game Dev Tycoon: think you can build the best games?It starts off slow: you're in a garage, with only so many topics open. You churn out game after game to earn your living.Then you get your first big hit. You hire an employee or two. You start to experiment more. And when you realize you're just one number off from the perfect hit, you start to analyze, tweak your formula a little and go "just one more game".Admittedly, it's not for everyone. You're going to spend a lot of time watching bubbles, watching charts and watching numbers spin. You'll probably grind for a while, just trying to keep the money flowing. But if you enjoy a strategy game that slowly gets more complicated and clever and makes you wonder how to do just a *little* bit better, here we go.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Não tem gráficos excelentes, não tem cutscenes nem jogabilidade dignas de registo. É um Tycoon simples. Mas... tão bem estruturado. É uma espécie de história da indústria dos videojogos, desde as primeiras máquinas às consolas e PCs topos de gama da actualidade. O tipo de jogos a desenvolver, a sua temática, o motor de jogo, o tipo de som, história, inteligência artificial, etc, etc... todos os pequenos pormenores acabam por entrar, de uma maneira ou de outra, no jogo. E, claro, há tipos de jogos que combinam com determinado tema e outros que funcionam de forma desastrosa. Não se faz um simulador de música, nem um RPG de corridas de carros. Há que acertar na escolha dos jogos a desenvolver e depois no tempo atribuído às diversas fases do seu desenvolvimento. Envolvente, e interessante, capaz de nos manter agarrados a jogar durante bastante tempo.É um excelente jogo casual, que surpreende pela positiva e entretém durante horas.
